{{for|the 2009 film based on the book|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)}} {{Infobox book | name = Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs | image = Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (book).jpg | caption = | author = [[Judi Barrett]] | illustrator = [[Ron Barrett]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | genre = [[Fantasy]] | publisher = [[Simon & Schuster]] | release_date = September 14, 1978 | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 0-689-30647-4 | followed_by = ''Pickles to Pittsburgh'' }} '''''Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs''''' is a children's book written by [[Judi Barrett]] and illustrated by [[Ron Barrett]]. It was first published in 1978 by the [[Simon & Schuster]] imprint [[Atheneum Books]], followed by a 1982 [[Paperback#Trade paperback|trade paperback]] edition from sister company [[Aladdin Paperbacks]].<ref>[http://www2.scholastic.com/browse/article.jsp?id=3752259 Scholastic.com: "''Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs'': Discussion Guide for Reading the Story"]</ref> Based on a 2007 online poll, the [[National Education Association]] named the book one of its "Teachers' Top 100 Books for Children".<ref name=NEA2007>{{cite web |url= http://www.nea.org/grants/13154.htm/ |title= Teachers' Top 100 Books for Children |author= National Education Association |year= 2007|accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> It was one of the "Top 100 Picture Books" of all time in a 2012 poll by ''[[School Library Journal]]''.<ref name=SLJPicture2012>{{cite web |url= http://blog.schoollibraryjournal.com/afuse8production/2012/07/06/top-100-picture-books-poll-results/ |title= Top 100 Picture Books Poll Results |author= Bird, Elizabeth | publisher=''[[School Library Journal]]'' "A Fuse #8 Production" blog|date= July 6, 2012 |accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref>
A sequel, ''Pickles to Pittsburgh'', was published in 2000 by Atheneum Books; a hardcover edition followed in 2009. A second sequel, ''Planet of the Pies'', was published on August 27, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Cloudy-With-Chance-Meatballs-Planet/dp/1442490276 | title=Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 3: Planet of the Pies: Judi Barrett, Isidre Mones: 9781442490277: Amazon.com: Books | publisher=Amazon.com | accessdate=2013-04-30}}</ref>
==Plot==
The book [[Frame story|details a bedtime story narrated]] by a grandfather to his grandchildren, chronicling the daily lives of the citizens of an unordinary town called Chewandswallow characterized by its strange daily meteorological pattern. Before the party is over, the town of Chewandswallow provides the townsfolk with all of their required daily meals by raining food.
But then, even though the residents of the town enjoy a lifestyle devoid of any grocery shopping or cookery, after many, many centuries, the weather unexpectedly and inexplicably takes a turn for the worse. Things start to go worse in Chewandswallow rather than better. The food in the weather devastates the local community with destructive and uncontrollable storms of either unpleasant or dangerously oversized foods, resulting in unstoppable catastrophes for the townspeople. Their lives endangered by the threats of the storms, they relocate to a different community of normal non-edible meteorological patterns (after deciding to permanently abandon Chewandswallow), safe from the hazards that once were presented by raining meals. However, they are now forced to adjust to a new land where it rains rain and snows snow and food can only be gotten in typical fashion. The place to get food from in the new land is from malls and grocery stores.
The following morning, the man's grandchildren awaken to discover snowfall. After bundling up and hurrying outside to play, the granddaughter, in first-person narration, describes how the sun looks like a pat of butter and the snow like mashed potatoes, so much so that she and Henry could almost smell them.
==Sequels== The follow up to the story, ''Pickles to Pittsburgh'', tells of the kids receiving a postcard from their grandfather, who claims to be visiting the ruins of what was once the fabled town of Chewandswallow. The kids then go to sleep and dream that they are there with him, helping to rebuild the post-apocalyptic landscape and restore it to where it is livable again, as well as giving the massive amounts of food away to poverty-stricken developing nations and homeless shelters around the world. This proves to be difficult, as there could be more food storms on the way.
A third book in the series, ''Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 3: Planet of the Pies'', was released on August 27, 2013. It details a dream Grandpa had about the first manned expedition to Mars, where Martian society is being overrun by daily storms of pies.
==Film adaptations== {{Main article|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (franchise)}} On September 18, 2009, [[Sony Pictures Animation]] released an animated [[Cloudy With A Chance of Meatballs (film)|film adaptation]] of the book, and the DVD was released on January 5, 2010. A new cast of characters were created for plot development, while the synopsis was changed from food falling from skies from meterology to being made from a machine. [[Bill Hader]] and [[Anna Faris]] provided the voices of the two lead characters. Hader voices Flint Lockwood, "a young inventor who dreams of creating something that will improve everyone's life." Faris provides the voice for Samantha "Sam" Sparks, "a weathergirl covering the caution who hides her intelligence behind a perky exterior." [[James Caan (actor)|James Caan]], [[Bruce Campbell]], [[Mr. T]], [[Andy Samberg]], [[Neil Patrick Harris]], [[Bobb'e J. Thompson]], [[Benjamin Bratt]], [[Al Roker]], [[Lauren Graham]], and [[Will Forte]] are also on the voice cast.<ref>Siegel, Tatiana. [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117992475.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 "Hader, Faris spice up 'Meatballs'; Caan, Samberg, Mr. T round out 3-D project"]. ''Variety''. September 18, 2008.</ref> Co-writers and co-directors Philip Lord and Chris Miller said that it would be a homage to, and a parody of, disaster movies such as ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]'', ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]'', ''[[The Core]]'', and ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=0&id=37514 |title=Meatballs Spoofs Disaster Flicks |accessdate=2008-12-05 |last=Lee |first=Patrick |coauthors= |date=2006-08-16 |work= |publisher=SCI FI Wire | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060821120206/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=0&id=37514| archivedate = August 21, 2006}}</ref>
Unlike the book where a grandfather tells his two grandchildren a bedtime story about Chewandswallow, an inventor named Flint Lockwood, who lives in Swallow Falls (Chewandswallow’s original name before the food weather), invents a machine that turns the water vapor in the atmosphere into food. Originally the phenomenon was limited to Swallow Falls, but overuse of the machine causes it to malfunction and the food weather taking a turn for the worse, as well as spreading it across the world. A sequel to the film, titled ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2]]'', was released on September 27, 2013, however, it is based on an original idea, and not ''Pickles to Pittsburgh''.
==Game== {{Main article|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (video game)}} In conjunction with the September 18, 2009 film release, [[Ubisoft]] released a game for [[Nintendo DS]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Wii]], and [[Xbox 360]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/04_01_09_12_17PM.htm|title=Video Games, News, Reviews, Walkthroughs, Cheat codes and More - Interact|first=|last=GameZone|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cloudyvideogame.us.ubi.com/#/home|title=Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs - Ubisoft|first=|last=Ubisoft|publisher=}}</ref> as well as a [[stereoscopy|stereoscopic]] online mini game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://static2.cdn.ubi.com/ncsa/CloudyMeatballs/minigame/cloudy.html|title=cloudy|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{About|the storytelling style|music produced from within a fictional world|Diegetic music}}{{Refimprove|date=September 2009}}
'''Diegesis''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|d|aɪ|ə|ˈ|dʒ|iː|s|ɪ|s}}; from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|διήγησις}} from {{lang|grc|διηγεῖσθαι}}, "to narrate") is a style of [[fictional|fiction]] storytelling that presents an interior view of a world in which: # details about the world itself and the experiences of its characters are revealed explicitly through narrative. # the story is told or recounted, as opposed to shown or enacted.<ref>Gerald Prince, A Dictionary of Narratology, 2003, University of Nebraska Press, {{ISBN|0-8032-8776-3}}</ref> # there is a presumed detachment from the story of both the speaker and the audience.
In diegesis, the [[narrator]] ''tells'' the story. The narrator presents the actions (and sometimes thoughts) of the characters to the readers or audience. Diegetic elements are part of the fictional world ("part of the story"), as opposed to non-diegetic elements which are stylistic elements of how the narrator tells the story ("part of the storytelling").
== In contrast to mimesis == ''Diegesis'' (Greek διήγησις "narration") and ''[[mimesis]]'' (Greek μίμησις "imitation") have been contrasted since [[Plato]]'s and [[Aristotle]]'s times. ''Mimesis'' ''shows'' rather than ''tells'', by means of action that is enacted. ''Diegesis'' is the ''telling'' of a [[Narrative|story]] by a [[narrator]]. The narrator may speak as a particular character, or may be the ''invisible narrator'', or even the ''all-knowing narrator'' who speaks from "outside" in the form of commenting on the action or the characters.
In Book III of his ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' (c. 373 BC), [[Plato]] examines the "style" of "poetry" (the term includes [[comedy]], [[tragedy]], [[Epic poetry|epic]] and [[lyric poetry]]):<ref>An [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext98/repub11.txt etext of Plato's ''Republic''] is available from [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/150 Project Gutenberg]. The most relevant section is the following: "You are aware, I suppose, that all mythology and poetry is a narration of events, either past, present, or to come? / Certainly, he replied. / And narration may be either simple narration, or imitation, or a union of the two? / [...] / And this assimilation of himself to another, either by the use of voice or gesture, is the imitation of the person whose character he assumes? / Of course. / Then in this case the narrative of the poet may be said to proceed by way of imitation? / Very true. / Or, if the poet everywhere appears and never conceals himself, then again the imitation is dropped, and his poetry becomes simple narration."([[Plato]], [[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]], Book III.)</ref> All types narrate events, he argues, but by differing means. He distinguishes between narration or report (''diegesis'') and imitation or representation (''[[mimesis]]''). Tragedy and comedy, he goes on to explain, are wholly imitative types; the [[dithyramb]] is wholly narrative; and their combination is found in [[epic poetry]]. When reporting or narrating, "the poet is speaking in his own person; he never leads us to suppose that he is any one else"; when imitating, the poet produces an "assimilation of himself to another, either by the use of voice or gesture".<ref>[[Plato]], [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext98/repub11.txt ''Republic''], Book III.</ref> In dramatic texts, the poet never speaks directly; in narrative texts, the poet speaks as him or herself.<ref>See also Pfister (1977, 2–3) and Elam: "classical narrative is always oriented towards an explicit ''there and then'', towards an imaginary "elsewhere" set in the past and which has to be evoked for the reader through predication and description. Dramatic worlds, on the other hand, are presented to the spectator as "hypothetically actual" constructs, since they are "seen" in progress "here and now" without narratorial mediation. [...] This is not merely a technical distinction but constitutes, rather, one of the cardinal principles of a poetics of the drama as opposed to one of narrative fiction. The distinction is, indeed, implicit in [[Aristotle]]'s differentiation of representational modes, namely ''[[Mimesis#Mimesis in contrast to diegesis|diegesis]]'' (narrative description) versus ''[[mimesis]]'' (direct imitation)" (1980, 110–111).</ref>
In his ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]'', the [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greek]] [[philosopher]] [[Aristotle]] argues that kinds of "poetry" (the term includes [[drama]], [[flute]] [[music]], and [[lyre]] music for Aristotle) may be differentiated in three ways: according to their ''medium'', according to their ''objects'', and according to their ''mode'' or "manner" (section I); "For the medium being the same, and the objects the same, the poet may imitate by narration—in which case he can either take another personality as Homer does, or speak in his own person, unchanged—or he may present all his characters as living and moving before us" (section III).
== Definition == In [[filmmaking]] the term is used to name the story depicted on screen, as opposed to the story in [[Real time (media)|real time]] that the screen narrative is about. Diegesis may concern elements, such as characters, events, and things within the main or ''primary'' narrative. However, the author may include elements that are not intended for the primary narrative, such as stories within stories. Characters and events may be referred to elsewhere or in historical contexts and are therefore outside the main story; thus, they are presented in an ''extradiegetic'' situation.
== In literature == For [[Narratology|narratologists]] all parts of narratives—characters, narrators, existents, actors—are characterized in terms of diegesis. For definitions of diegesis, one should consult Aristotle's ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]''; [[Gerard Genette]]'s ''Narrative Discourse: An Essay in Method'' (Cornell University Press, 1980); or (for a readable introduction) H. Porter Abbott's ''The Cambridge Introduction to Narrative'' (Cambridge University Press 2002). In literature, discussions of diegesis tend to concern discourse/sjužet (in [[Russian Formalism]]) (vs. story/[[Fabula and syuzhet|fabula]]).
Diegesis is multi-levelled in narrative fiction. Genette distinguishes between three "diegetic levels". The '''extradiegetic level''' (the level of the narrative's telling) is, according to Prince, "external to (not part of) any diegesis." One might think of this as what we commonly understand to be the narrator's level, the level at which exists a narrator who is not part of the story being told. The '''diegetic level''' or '''intradiegetic level''' is understood as the level of the characters, their thoughts and actions. The '''metadiegetic level''' or '''hypodiegetic level''' is that part of a diegesis that is embedded in another one and is often understood as a [[story within a story]], as when a diegetic narrator himself/herself tells a story.
== In film == The classical distinction between the diegetic mode and the mimetic mode relate to the difference between the ''epos'' (or [[epic poetry]]) and ''drama''.<ref>Elam (1980, 110–111).</ref> The "epos" relates stories by ''telling'' them through narration, while drama enacts stories through direct embodiment (''showing''). In terms of classical [[Poetics (Aristotle)|poetics]], the cinema is an ''epic'' form that utilizes ''dramatic'' elements; this is determined by the technologies of ''the camera'' and ''editing''. Even in a spatially and temporally continuous scene (mimicking the theatrical situation, as it were), the camera ''chooses'' where to look for us. In a similar way, editing causes us to jump from one place (and/or time) to another, whether it be elsewhere in the room, or across town. This jump is a form of narration; it is as if a narrator whispers to us: "meanwhile, on the other side of the forest". It is for this reason that the "story-world" in cinema is referred to as "diegetic"; elements that belong to the film's narrative world are diegetic elements. This is why, in the cinema, we may refer to the film's ''diegetic world''.
"Diegetic", in the cinema, typically refers to the internal world created by the story that the characters themselves experience and encounter: the narrative "space" that includes all the parts of the story, both those that are and those that are not actually shown on the screen (such as events that have led up to the present action; people who are being talked about; or events that are presumed to have happened elsewhere or at a different time).
Thus, elements of a film can be "diegetic" or "non-diegetic". These terms are most commonly used in reference to sound in a film, but can apply to other elements. For example, an insert shot that depicts something that is neither taking place in the world of the film, nor is seen, imagined, or thought by a character, is a [[non-diegetic insert]]. Titles, subtitles, and [[voice-over]] narration (with some exceptions) are also non-diegetic.
== In video games == In video games "diegesis" comprises the narrative game world, its characters, objects and actions which can be classified as "intra-diegetic", by both being part of the narration and not breaking the [[fourth wall]].<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://devmag.org.za/2011/02/02/video-game-user-interface-design-diegesis-theory/ |title=Video game user interface design: Diegesis theory| last=Russell| first=Dave| date=2011-02-02| website=Dev.Mag| access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref> Status icons, menu bars and other UI which are not part of the game world itself can be considered as "extra-diegetic"; a game character does not know about them even though for the player they may present crucial information. A noted example of a diegetic interface in video games is that of the ''[[Dead Space (series)|Dead Space]]'' series, in which the player-character is equipped with an advanced survival suit that projects holographic images to the character within the game's rendering engine that also serve as the game's user-interface to the player to show weapon selection, inventory management, and special actions that can be taken.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2013/3/31/4166250/dead-space-user-interface-gdc-2013| title = Deliberately diegetic: Dead Space's lead interface designer chronicles the UI's evolution at GDC| publisher = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]| date = 13 March 2013| accessdate = 15 April 2015| first = Dave| last = Tach}}</ref>

{{weasel|date=May 2014}} '''Dr. Sketchy's Anti-Art School''' is both a [[burlesque]] [[cabaret]] and [[life drawing]] event originating in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]], [[Brooklyn]], at the Lucky Cat. Dr. Sketchy's was founded in [[New York City]] in 2005, by [[illustrator]] and former artist's model [[Molly Crabapple]] and illustrator [[A.V. Phibes]] who later left to attend to her design studio.<ref name=NewYorkTimes>Kino, Carol (October 2, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/04/arts/design/04kino.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 "A World Drawn From Wild Tastes"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
Described as a cross between an old-fashioned life-drawing session and a new-wave cabaret, it usually meets every other Saturday at [[the Slipper Room]], a burlesque-themed bar on Orchard Street in Manhattan (though Crabapple has held it at other locations like Times Square), where approximately 50 artists, web designers, cartoonists and hipsters pay $12 each to draw a downtown personalities such as alternative model Raquel Reed or performance artist Amber Ray.<ref name=NewYorkTimes/> In a typical sketching session, artists will drink alcohol, sketch burlesque models, and play art games in a bar or venue like an art museum. Crabapple will often travel around the world visiting different Dr. Sketchy's.<ref>Wright, Jennifer (2010). [http://www.cityist.com/features/molly_crabapple/ "A Graphic Artist: Whimsical illustrator Molly Crabapple thinks outside The Box"]. ''Cityist''. Retrieved June 14, 2014.</ref> As of 2009 there are branches of Dr. Sketchy's Anti-Art School all over the world.<ref name=NewYorkTimes/>
''The Official Dr. Sketchy's Rainy Day Colouring Book'', by Molly Crabapple and John Leavitt, was released by Sepulculture Books in December 2006, and is in its second printing. Other projects include a 2008 pin-up calendar, a series of YouTube comedy shorts, a national tour, an art show, and a 21-show run at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]].
In 2010, a short documentary by Peter Bolte was made about ''Dr. Sketchy''.
Despite conservatism in continents such as Asia, Dr. Sketchy's appears to be widely accepted in Tokyo, Singapore and the Philippines. The Singapore branch is headlined by the zesty{{weasel word|date=May 2014}} Becca D'Bus. The Philippine branch is one of Crabapple's favorite new branches.<ref>[http://www.dontpaniconline.com/magazine/arts/molly-crabapple/ MOLLY CRABAPPLE] on [http://www.dontpaniconline.com Don't Panic Online Magazine]</ref>

{{Use American English|date=November 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox military person |image = Private Edwin Francis Jemison.jpg |caption = Jemison in uniform, [[Circa|ca.]] 1861 |birth_date = {{birth date|1844|12|1}} |death_date = {{death date and age|1862|7|1|1844|12|1}} |birth_place = [[Milledgeville, Georgia|Milledgeville]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_place = [[Henrico County, Virginia|Henrico County]], [[Virginia]], [[Confederate States of America|C.S.]] | allegiance = {{flag|Confederate States|1861}} | branch = {{army|CSA|size=23px}} | serviceyears = 1861–1862 |rank = [[Private (rank)|Private]] |unit= Company C, 2d Louisiana Infantry |battles = [[American Civil War]] *[[Peninsula Campaign]] **[[Battle of Malvern Hill]]{{KIA}} }} '''Edwin Francis Jemison''' (December 1, 1844 – July 1, 1862) was a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] soldier who served in Company C, 2d Louisiana Infantry, from May 1861 until he was [[killed in action|killed]] at the [[Battle of Malvern Hill]].<ref>{{cite news|title=[[:File:Edwin_Francis_Jemison_obituary.jpg|Obituary: Edwin Francis Jemison]] |work=Southern Recorder|date=5 Aug 1862|page=3}}</ref>
==American Civil War== Jemison enlisted on May 11, 1861, and was among the war's early [[Military volunteer|volunteer]]s.<ref name=exploresouthernhistory>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Dale|title=Best Known Confederate Soldier|url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/jemison.html|website=ExploreSouthernHistory|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref> He participated in the [[Peninsula Campaign]] under Maj. Gen. [[John B. Magruder|Magruder]].<ref>{{cite book |last = Field |first = Ron |author2=Hook, Richard |title=The Confederate Army 1861-65 (3): Louisiana & Texas |publisher=Osprey Publishing |year=2006 |page=17 |isbn=1846030315}}</ref>
==Killed in action== Jemison was killed on July 1, 1862, at the [[Battle of Malvern Hill]], reportedly by a direct hit from a [[Round shot|cannonball]] which decapitated him.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jones |first=Terry L. |title=The Louisiana Journey |publisher=Gibbs Smith |year=2006 |page=193 |isbn=1423601300 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rn4p-eFL6oMC&lpg=PP1&dq=editions%3AIiZyDqsYvvMC&pg=PA193}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Miller|first=William J.|title=The Two Pictures of Private Jemison|journal=America's Civil War|date=May 2004|page=32}}</ref> His death by cannon fire is corroborated by the 1887 obituary of his younger brother, Sam, but incorrectly identifies the battle as [[First Manassas]].<ref>{{cite news|title=End of a Brilliant Lawyer|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2875546/obituary_of_samuel_hunter_jemison/|accessdate=24 July 2015|work=The Ouachita Telegraph|date=1 Jan 1887|quote=the second was killed, with his messmate, by a cannon shot at the first battle of Manassas}}</ref> Following the Battle of Malvern Hill, both sides buried their dead on the battlefield. After the [[American Civil War]], organizations like the [[United Daughters of the Confederacy]] returned to the old battlefields and disinterred the bodies of fallen Confederate soldiers and gave them proper burials in places like the Confederate Section of [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]] in nearby [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], [[Virginia]]. It is thought that Jemison's parents erected the monument to him at Memory Hill Cemetery in [[Milledgeville, Georgia|Milledgeville]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], where he may be buried.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Filipowski |first=Alexandra |author2=Harrington |title=Hugh T. |journal=America's Civil War |date=May 2007 |page=28}}</ref><ref name=exploresouthernhistory /> Most believe that he was buried on or near the Malvern Hill battlefield in [[Henrico County, Virginia|Henrico County]], Virginia, in an unmarked grave.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Filipowski|first1=Alexandra|last2=Harrington|first2=Hugh T.|title=America's Civil War: Where Does Private Jemison Rest|journal=America's Civil War|date=May 2004|url=http://www.historynet.com/americas-civil-war-where-does-private-jemison-rest.htm|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref>
==Legacy== Jemison's photograph has become one of the most famous and iconic portraits of the young soldiers of both the Confederate and [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] armies.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Associated Press |title=Identity of Civil War soldier corrected |url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/19960528/NEWS/305289977 |website=SouthCoastToday |accessdate=24 July 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724200904/http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/19960528/NEWS/305289977 |archivedate=24 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/13976014| title = Edwin Francis Jemison|publisher =[[Find A Grave]]| accessdate = 21 May 2012}}</ref>

{{for|the Fountain of the Tritons|Fontana dei Tritoni}} {{for|the Triton Fountain in Malta|Triton Fountain (Malta)}} [[File:Fontana del Tritone,Rome.jpg|thumb|''Fontana del Tritone'' by [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]], Piazza Barberini, Rome]]
'''Fontana del Tritone''' (''Triton Fountain'') is a seventeenth-century fountain in Rome, by the [[Baroque]] sculptor [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]]. Commissioned by his patron, Pope [[Urban VIII]], the fountain is located in the Piazza Barberini, near the entrance to the [[Palazzo Barberini]] (which now houses the [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica]]) that Bernini helped to design and construct for the [[Barberini]], Urban's family.<ref>The Palazzo Barberini was built according to a plan by the architect [[Carlo Maderno]]. When Maderno died in 1629, Bernini took over supervising its construction. Both the fountain and palace are close to [[Borromini]]'s [[San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane]]</ref> This fountain should be distinguished from the nearby ''Fontana dei Tritoni'' (Fountain of the Tritons) by [[Carlo Francesco Bizzaccheri]] in [[Piazza Bocca della Verità]] which features two Tritons.
The [[fountain]] was executed in [[travertine]] in 1642–43. At its centre rises a larger than lifesize muscular [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]], a minor sea god of ancient Greco-Roman legend, depicted as a [[merman]] kneeling on the sum of four dolphin tailfins. His head is thrown back and his arms raise a [[conch]] to his lips; from it a jet of water spurts, formerly rising dramatically higher than it does today. The fountain has a base of four [[dolphin]]s<ref>The dolphins are represented in their heraldic conventionalization, not as they appear in nature.</ref> that entwine the [[papal tiara]] with crossed keys and the heraldic [[Barberini]] bees in their scaly tails.<ref>Two finished terracotta ''[[Glossary of sculpting terms|bozzetti]]'' at the [[Detroit Institute of Arts]], (accession numbers 52.218 and 52.219) securely attributed to Bernini, reflect his exploration of the fountain's themes of the intertwined upended dolphins and the muscular, scaly-tailed Triton.</ref>
The ''Tritone'', the first of Bernini's free-standing urban fountains, was erected to provide water from the [[Acqua Felice]] aqueduct which Urban had restored, in a dramatic celebration. It was Bernini's last major commission from his great patron who died in 1644. At the Triton Fountain, Urban and Bernini brought the idea of a sculptural fountain, familiar from [[villa]] gardens, decisively to a public urban setting for the first time; previous public fountains in the city of Rome had been passive basins for the reception of public water.
Bernini has represented the triton to illustrate the triumphant passage from [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses (poem)|Metamorphoses]]'' book I, evoking godlike control over the waters and describing the draining away of the [[Deluge (mythology)|Universal Deluge]]. The passage that Urban set Bernini to illustrate, was well known to all literate Roman contemporaries:
:''Already Triton, at his call, appears :''Above the waves; a Tyrian robe he wears; :''And in his hand a crooked trumpet bears. :''The sovereign bids him peaceful sounds inspire, :''And give the waves the signal to retire. :''His writhen shell he takes; whose narrow vent :''Grows by degrees into a large extent, :''Then gives it breath; the blast with doubling sound, :''Runs the wide circuit of the world around: :''The sun first heard it, in his early east, :''And met the rattling ecchos in the west. :''The waters, list'ning to the trumpet's roar, :''Obey the summons, and forsake the shore. :::—free translation by Sir Samuel Garth, John Dryden, et al..<!--retaining original spelling-->
Two finished terracotta ''[[Glossary of sculpting terms|bozzetti]]'' at the [[Detroit Institute of Arts]],<ref>Accession numbers 52.218 and 52.219.</ref> securely attributed to Bernini, reflect his exploration of the fountain's themes of the intertwined upended dolphins and the muscular, scaly-tailed Triton.
==Subsequent history== [[File:Sculptures of dolphins in Fontana del Tritone (Rome).jpg|thumb|''Fontana del Tritone'' dolphins heads]] The Triton Fountain is one of those evoked in [[Ottorino Respighi]]'s ''[[Fontane di Roma]]''. The legend applied to [[Trevi Fountain]] has been extended to this: that any visitor who throws a coin into the water (while facing away from the fountain) will have guaranteed their return to Rome.
The setting of the Piazza Barberini has changed significantly since the seventeenth century. Engravings of the time and photographs from the nineteenth century show much lower buildings around the piazza, which would have made the fountain much more dramatic. However, it is a tribute to the artistic judgement of Bernini that even now, with tall buildings around the traffic-ridden piazza, that the Triton Fountain can still maintain a dramatic presence.

{{Infobox artwork | image_file=File:Gloucester Harbor William Morris Hunt.jpeg | caption= | alt= |image_size = | title=Gloucester Harbor | other_language_1= | other_title_1= | other_title_2= | artist=[[William Morris Hunt]] | subject= | year={{circa}} 1877 | material=Oil on canvas | height_metric=53 | width_metric=79 | city=Boston | museum=Museum of Fine Arts }} '''''Gloucester Harbor''''' is a late 19th century painting by American artist [[William Morris Hunt]]. Done in oil on canvas, the impressionist painting depicts morning in the harbor of [[Gloucester, Massachusetts|Gloucester]], a major fishing port in [[New England]]. The painting was one of Hunt's first forays into the school of impressionism, and the creation of ''Gloucester Harbor'' and several other impressionism-inflected works sparked Bostonian interest in the impressionist movement. The painting is currently on display at the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mfa.org/collections/object/gloucester-harbor-32897|title=Gloucester Harbor|date=2017-03-01|work=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en}}</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} {{19C-painting-stub}}

Calling „'''Helga!'''“ is a [[running gag]] at German concerts and festivals.
== Ritual== A person may call for a ''[[Helga]]'',<ref name="Neon">[http://www.neon.de/kat/freie_zeit/musik/88151.html Das Festival] auf neon.de</ref> others answer and come to a chorus like group effect.<ref>[http://www.faqs.org/faqs/de/music/faq/ <2004-04-14> Allgemeine Musiknewsgruppen-FAQ] auf faqs.org</ref> „Helga ist tot!“ (Helga is dead) denies the helgaing request.<ref>Julia Thiel: [http://www.einslive.de/musik/extras/2011/06/festival_abc.jsp Das Festival-ABC] auf einslive.de</ref> Further allegations se gravestones, memorials or graffiti. The background is unknown, some reports point to a rather rainy [[Hurricane Festival]] in [[Scheeßel]], where a high pressure cyclone called Helga was called for but didn't arrive in time. The call was namegiver for an annual prize for German festivals.<ref>[http://www.festivalguide.de/derhelga/ Der Helga]</ref> and is being used by a service company.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/wunderbar/festival-rituale-oliver-uschmann-ueber-crowdsurfing-und-helga-rufe-a-828387-4.html Rituale auf Festivals: Götter im Dixi, erhöret uns], Spiegel 2012 </ref>

{{Infobox Organization |image = InstituteofArtandIdeas2016.png |imagesize = 100px | |name = Institute of Art and Ideas |formation = 2008 |industry = |location = Hay-on-Wye, Wales, U.K. |leader_title = Founder |leader_name = Hilary Lawson |website = [http://iai.tv/ www.iai.tv] }} The '''Institute of Art and Ideas'''https://iai.tv/about-iai/introducing-iai is an arts organisation founded in 2008 in London. Its programming includes the world's largest philosophy and music festival, [[HowTheLightGetsIn]]{{cite web|url=https://iai.tv/about-iai/introducing-iai |title=Introducting the IAI. |publisher=Institute of Art and Ideas |date= |accessdate=2016-01-15}} and the online channel [https://iai.tv/player IAI TV], where talks and debates can be accessed for free, under the slogan "Philosophy for our times." The IAI's main offering, [[HowTheLightGetsIn]], is held annually in [[Hay-on-Wye]] at the globe at Hay.{{cite web|url=http://www.globeathay.org/about-us/ |title=About the globe. |publisher=The globe at Hay |date= |accessdate=2016-01-15}} The IAI is led by its founding director, the British post-realist philosopher and former broadcaster [[Hilary Lawson]].{{cite web|url=https://iai.tv/home/host/hilary-lawson |title=Hilary Lawson: Profile. |publisher=Institute of Art and Ideas |date= |accessdate=2016-01-15}} ==IAI TV== IAI TV is an online channel where the debates and talks curated by the IAI are released and made available online. Subjects include philosophy, science, politics and art. In September 2016 the videos had received in excess of 670,000 views, reaching over 1,000,000 people each year.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesartsreview.org/interview-hilary-lawson-director-of-how-the-light-gets-in/ |title=Interview: Hilary Lawson, Director of How the Light Gets In. |publisher=Wales Art Review |date= |accessdate=2016-11-30}} Hilary Lawson in an interview in 2014:
"One of the things we're up to is breaking down the idea of philosophy as being the sort of thing that is undertaken only by a specialist and is impenetrable. Not to say laughable, frankly. And I think when we started – I founded the Institute of Art and Ideas seven years ago, two years before the first HowTheLightGetsIn – that was indeed the only way people thought about philosophy. But every human being, in a way, is a philosopher. Because that's what it is to be human. You wonder about life. You wonder about what you're doing. You wonder about where you're going. You wonder: "What the hell's going on"'.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2014/apr/27/howthelightgetsin-2014-philosophy-music-hay-on-wye |title=HowTheLightGetsIn 2014: philosophy, music and thought for all |publisher=The Guardian |date=27 April 2014 |accessdate=2017-08-18}}
===IAI Academy=== IAI Academy is an educational platform of free online courses in philosophy, politics, art and science. Since September 2016, new courses have been published on a monthly basis. Open Culture cited it for helping foster "a progressive and vibrant intellectual culture".{{cite web|url=http://www.openculture.com/2014/10/iai-academy.html |title=IAI Academy Now Offers Free Courses: From "The Meaning of Life" to "A Brief Guide to Everything" |publisher=Open Culture |date= |accessdate=2016-11-30}} ==Philosophy for Our Times == Beginning in September 2016, the IAI has been publishing its weekly podcast, ''Philosophy for our Times'', featuring the debates from HowTheLightGetsIn. {{cite web|url=https://iai.tv/about-iai/introducing-iai |title=iai Podcasts: Philosophy for our times |publisher=Institute of Art and Ideas |date= |accessdate=2016-12-14}} == Crunch: the Art and Music Festival at Hay == [[Crunch Festival|Crunch]] was an annual Art and Music festival{{cite web|url=http://artfestivalathay.org/ |title=Crunch: the art and music festival at hay |publisher=Artfestivalathay.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-09}} that took place each November in [[Hay-on-Wye]], [[Wales]]. It was held by the Institute of Art and Ideas, a non-profit organization which hosts a number of cultural events throughout the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.artandideas.org/ |title=Institute of Art & Ideas: Philosophy & Big Ideas » IAI TV |publisher=Artandideas.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-09}} Crunch brought together the world's leading artists, curators and critics to debate the questions that lie at the core of contemporary art. The 3-day festival featured talk sessions and debates, live music, performance acts, creative workshops, art exhibitions and late night parties. == Notes and references == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Institute Of Art And Ideas}} [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:British culture]] [[Category:Cultural organisations based in Wales]] [[Category:English-language education]] [[Category:Philosophy institutes]] [[Category:Philosophical media]]

'''The University of Arts of Cuba / Instituto Superior de Arte''' ('''ISA''') was established on September 1, 1976, by the Cuban government as a school for the arts. Its original structure had three schools: [[Music]], [[Visual Arts]], and [[Performing Arts]].
At present the ISA has four schools, the previous three and one for Arts and Audiovisual Communication Media. There are also four teaching schools in the provinces, one in [[Camagüey]], two in [[Holguín]] and one in [[Santiago de Cuba]].
ISA offers pre-degree and post-degree courses, as well as a wide spectrum of brief and extension courses, including preparation for Cuban and foreign professors for a degree of Doctor on Sciences in Art.
Predegree education has increased to five careers: Music, Visual Arts, Theatre Arts, Dance Arts and Arts and Audiovisual Communication Media.
In 1996, the ISA established the ''National Award of Artistic Teaching'', conceived for recognizing a lifework devoted to arts teaching.
==Notable faculty== *[[José Villa Soberón]], professor of sculpture *[[Evelio Tieles]], Professor and Consultant Professor of Violin (School of Music)

[[DreamWorks Television]] | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 26 (7 unaired) | website = }} '''''It's Like, You Know...''''' is an American [[sitcom]] television series broadcast by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. It starred [[Steven Eckholdt]], [[Chris Eigeman]], [[Evan Handler]], [[A. J. Langer]], and [[Jennifer Grey]], and depicted life in Los Angeles as viewed through the eyes of Eigeman's character, a diehard New Yorker named Arthur Garment. The series aired for two seasons, from March 24, 1999 until January 5, 2000. ==Synopsis== The show sought to lampoon an upper class Los Angeles lifestyle, in part by presenting the Manhattan writer, Garment, as a fish out of water among Hollywood notables and the idle rich. In the pilot his character arrives with unconcealed hostility, intent on treating his readers to a bitter satire on the absurdities and excesses of LA culture. While staying with an old friend from college, Garment finds himself increasingly torn between button-down stern contempt for West Coast attitudes and a growing enchantment with the relaxed whimsy constantly swirling around him. The show was also notable for featuring the actress Jennifer Grey playing herself, the source of a running joke related to her real-life [[rhinoplasty]].{{cite web |author=Huff, Richard |date=March 28, 1999 |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-03-28/entertainment/18101411_1_mehlman-nose-jennifer-grey |title=Like, You Know... L.a. Has A Funny Bone, Too |work=[[New York Daily News]] |access-date=}} ==Cast== *[[Steven Eckholdt]] as Robbie Graham *[[Chris Eigeman]] as Arthur Garment *[[Evan Handler]] as Shrug *[[A. J. {{Art of Italy}} '''[[Italy|Italian]] [[Rococo]] [[art]]''' refers to [[painting]] and the [[plastic arts]] in Italy during the [[Rococo]] period, which went from about the early/mid-18th to the late 18th century.
==History and background== Italian Rococo was mainly inspired by the [[rocaille]] or French Rococo, since [[France]] was the founding nation of that particular style. The styles of the Italian Rococo were very similar to those of France. The style in Italy was usually lighter and more feminine than [[Italian Baroque art]], and became the more popular art form of the [[History of Italian culture (1700s)|settecento]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}}<!--citation[s] for entire paragraph, please-->
The leading artistic centres during the [[Rococo]] in Italy were [[Venice]], [[Genoa]] and [[Rome]]. Most Italian Rococo artists came from [[Venice]], such as [[Canaletto]], [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo|Tiepolo]], [[Guardi]], [[Piazzetta]] and [[Bernardo Bellotto|Bellotto]],<ref>http://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/entertainment/italian-art-the-rococo-period.html</ref> but also from [[Rome]] and [[Genoa]], such as [[Giovanni Battista Piranesi|Piranesi]] and [[Giovanni Paolo Pannini|Pannini]]. Artists such as [[Giuseppe Castiglione (Jesuit)|Castiglione]] and [[Alessandro Magnasco]] brought the vogue of Rococo art to [[Genoa]], and [[Naples|Neapolitan]] Rococo was mainly based on landscapes and naturalistic themes.<ref>http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/ent/A0858942.html</ref> [[Canaletto]] and [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo|Tiepolo]] were among the most prominent painters of the age, and they painted many frescos and cityscapes (particularly Canaletto).
==List of painters== A list of Italian Rococo painters:, [[Sirio Antonio Africa]], [[Jacopo Amigoni]], [[Marcello Bacciarelli]], [[Antonio Balestra]], [[Francesco Bambocci]], [[Pompeo Batoni]], [[Antonio Bellucci]], [[Bernardo Bellotto]], [[Giovanni Antonio Canal]], (or il Canaletto), [[Carlo Innocenzo Carloni]], [[Andrea Casali]], [[Placido Costanzi]], [[Giovanni Antonio Cucchi]], [[Carlo Angelo dal Verme]], [[Antonio De Giorgi]], [[Stefano Fabbrini]], [[Federico Ferrari]], [[Francesco Fontebasso]], [[Francesco Liani]], [[Pier Leone Ghezzi]], [[Corrado Giaquinto]], [[Ignazio Hughford]], [[Andrea Locatelli]], [[Pietro Longhi]], [[Giovanni Battista Lusieri]], [[Alessandro Magnasco]], [[Mauro Soderini]], [[Giuseppe Moriani]], [[Francesco de Mura]], [[Domenico Pellegrini (painter)|Domenico Pellegrini]], [[Giovanni Antonio Pellegrini]], [[Giovanni Battista Piazzetta]], [[Antonio Pillori]], [[Giovanni Battista Pittoni]], [[Giovanni Paolo Panini]], [[Ferdinando Porta]], [[Michele Rocca]], [[Pietro Antonio Rotari]], [[Giovanni Scajario]], [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo]], [[Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo]], [[Stefano Torelli]], [[Francesco Zuccarelli]], [[Francesco Zugno]].

{{Sculpture | image = [[Image:Lucifer Liege Luc Viatour new.jpg|250px]] | title = Le génie du mal | artist = [[Guillaume Geefs]] | year = 1848 | type = [[marble|white marble]] | city = [[Liège (city)|Liège]] | museum = [[St. Paul's Cathedral (Liège)|St. Paul's Cathedral]] }}
'''''Le génie du mal''''' (installed 1848) or ''The [[Genius (mythology)|Genius]] of Evil'' or the genie of evil or the spirit of evil, known informally in English as '''''[[Lucifer]]''''' or '''''The Lucifer of Liège''''',<ref>"Le génie du mal" could also be translated as ''Evil Genius'' or even ''Evil Spirit''. French ''génie'' in this sense can overlap in meaning with its English [[Cognate (etymology)#Cognates across languages|cognate]] "[[Genie#Etymology and definitions|genie]]". The [[:fr:Accueil|French Wikipédia]] article on [[:fr:Génie du mal|Génie du mal]] deals with the stock character of the "evil genius" in fiction, film, and popular culture. Geefs may have had in mind the [[Genius#Philosophy|Kantian conception of genius]], which influenced [[Romanticism]] in the 19th century.</ref> is a religious sculpture executed in white marble by the [[Belgium|Belgian]] artist [[Guillaume Geefs]]. [[Francophone]] [[art historian]]s most often refer to the figure as an ''ange déchu'', a "[[fallen angel]]". It is located within the elaborate [[pulpit]] (French ''chaire de vérité'', "seat of truth") of [[St. Paul's Cathedral (Liège)|St. Paul's Cathedral]], [[Liège (city)|Liège]], and depicts a [[Classicism|classically]] [[Physical attractiveness|beautiful]] man in his physical prime, chained, seated, and nearly [[Depictions of nudity|nude]] but for drapery gathered over his thighs, his full length ensconced within a [[mandorla]] of [[Bat (animal)|bat]] wings. Geefs' work replaces an earlier sculpture created for the space by his younger brother [[Joseph Geefs]], ''[[:File:L'ange du mal (Joseph Geefs) cropped.jpg|L'ange du mal]]'', which was removed from the [[cathedral]] because of its distracting allure and "unhealthy beauty".<ref>In French, ''beauté malsaine'': [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], ''Le génie du mal'' by Joseph Geefs, Fabritius online catalogue [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/fabritiusweb/FullBB.csp?WebAction=ShowFullBB&RequestId=68766_2&Profile=Default&OpacLanguage=fre&NumberToRetrieve=10&StartValue=85&WebPageNr=1&SearchTerm1=GEEFSJOSEPH%20.2.3570&SearchT1=&Index1=Index24b&SearchMethod=Find_1&ItemNr=5 description.]</ref>
In the late 1980s, a photograph of ''Le génie du mal'' became a focal point of ''[[Le génie du mal#Himmelsweg|Himmelsweg]]'', an [[Installation art|art installation]] by the Liège-born artist [[:fr:Jacques Charlier|Jacques Charlier]] on the theme of seductive evil and the danger of obscuring the memory of [[the Holocaust]].
==Two spirits, one site== [[File:Guillaume Geefs portrait.jpg|thumb|120px|left|[[Guillaume Geefs]]]] ''Le génie du mal'' is set within an open [[Niche (architecture)|niche]] formed at the base of twin ornate staircases carved with [[Gothic architecture|gothic]] floral [[Motif (visual arts)|motifs]].<ref>The sculpture may be viewed in its architectural setting [http://www.wittert.ulg.ac.be/expo/19e/album/img/musees/geefs_genie_x.jpg online], and at an angle showing the [[stained glass]] windows [http://veroniqueliege.skynetblogs.be/tag/1/LIEGE-SENSUEL also online.] The view with stained glass windows is preserved also at the [[WebCite]] [https://www.webcitation.org/5gOjipWe8?url=http://veroniqueliege.skynetblogs.be/tag/1/LIEGE-SENSUEL archive.]</ref> The curved railing of the [[stairway#Spiral and helical stairs|semi-spiral stairs]] reiterates the arc of the wings, which are retracted and cup the body. The versions by Guillaume and Joseph are strikingly similar at first glance and appear inspired by the same [[Model (art)|human model]]. For each, the fallen angel sits on a rock, sheltered by his folded wings; his upper [[torso]], arms, and legs are nude, his center-parted hair [[nape]]-length. The veined, membranous wings are articulated like a bat's, with a prominent thumb claw; the knobby, sinewy [[olecranon]] combines bat and human [[anatomy]] to create an illusion of [[Realism (visual arts)|realism]].<ref>Soo Yang Geuzaine et Alexia Creusen, "Guillaume Geefs: ''Le Génie du Mal'' (1848) à la cathédrale Saint-Paul de Liège," ''Vers la modernité. Le XIX<sup>e</sup> siècle au Pays de Liège'', [http://www.wittert.ulg.ac.be/expo/19e/album/165_geefs_genie.html online catalogue] of an exhibition presented by the University of Liège from 5 October 2001 to 20 January 2002.</ref> A broken [[sceptre]] and stripped-off [[Crown (headgear)|crown]] are held at the right [[Hip#Cultural significance of hips|hip]]. The white-[[marble sculpture]]s occupy approximately the same [[dimension]]s, delimited by the space; Guillaume's measures 165 by 77 by 65 cm, or nearly five-and-a-half feet in height, with Joseph's only slightly larger at 168.5 by 86 by 65.5 cm.<ref>Michael Palmer ''et al.'', ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=eIhHTre5wYoC&pg=PT206 500 chefs-d'oeuvre de l'art belge du XV<sup>e</sup> siècle à nos jours]'' (Éditions Racine, n.d.), p. 203 [ online.]</ref>
==The commission== [[File:Pulpit St. Paul's Liège (Geefs).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Pulpit of St. Paul's Cathedral, Liège, in a 1900 illustration by [[Médard Tytgat]]; ''Le génie du mal'' is on the unseen side]] [[File:Chaire Cathédrale Liège 240809 01.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The pulpit in a 2009 photograph]] In 1837, Guillaume Geefs was put in charge of designing the elaborate pulpit for St. Paul's, the theme of which was "the Triumph of Religion over the Genius of Evil". Geefs had come to prominence creating [[monument]]al and [[public art|public sculptures]] in honor of political figures, expressing and capitalizing on the [[Nationalism|nationalist]] spirit that followed [[Belgian Revolution|Belgian independence in 1830]]. Techniques of [[Realism (arts)|realism]] coupled with [[Neoclassicism|Neoclassical]] restraint discipline any tendency toward [[Romanticism|Romantic heroism]] in these works, but Romanticism was to express itself more strongly in the Lucifer project.<ref>Geuzaine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''; [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], 19th-century sculpture collection [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/fr/frames/F_sculpture.html online introduction.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322045449/http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/FR/frames/F_sculpture.html |date=2009-03-22 }}</ref>
From the outset, sculpture was an integral part of Geefs' pulpit design, which featured representations of the saints [[Saint Peter|Peter]], [[Saint Paul|Paul]], [[Hubertus|Hubert]] the first [[Prince-Bishopric of Liège|Bishop of Liège]], and [[Lambert of Maastricht]]. A drawing of the pulpit by the Belgian illustrator [[Médard Tytgat]], published in 1900, shows the front; ''Le génie du mal'' would be located at the base of the stairs on the opposite side, but the book in which the illustration appears omits mention of the work.<ref>Illustration by [[Médard Tytgat]] in Eloi Bartholeyns, ''Guillaume Geefs: sa vie et ses œuvres'' (Brussels: Schaerbeek, 1900), pp. 105 and 112.</ref>
The commission was originally awarded to Geefs' younger brother Joseph, who completed ''[[:File:L'ange du mal (Joseph Geefs) cropped.jpg|L'ange du mal]]'' in 1842 and installed it the following year. It generated controversy at once and was criticized for not representing a [[Christianity|Christian]] ideal.<ref>''Ne rendant pas l'idée chrétienne'': quoted by Vicky Chris, [http://es.treklens.com/gallery/Europe/Belgium/photo425244.htm TrekLens.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115211210/http://es.treklens.com/gallery/Europe/Belgium/photo425244.htm |date=2017-11-15 }}</ref> The cathedral administration declared that "this devil is too sublime."<ref>"Ce diable-là est trop sublime": originally quoted in ''L'Émancipation'', 4 August 1844, as cited by [[Jacques Van Lennep]], ''La Sculpture belge au xixe siècle, exposition organisée à Bruxelles du 5 octobre au 15 décembre 1990, La Générale de banque, Bruxelles'' (Exhibition catalogue, 1990); Geuzaine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''.</ref> The local press intimated that the work was distracting the "pretty penitent girls" who should have been listening to the sermons.<ref>Edmond Marchal, "Étude sur la vie et les œuvres de Joseph-Charles Geefs," ''Annuaire de l'Académie Royale des sciences, des lettres et des beaux-arts de Belgique'' (Brussels, 1888), p. 316.</ref> [[Cornelius Richard Anton van Bommel|Bishop van Bommel]] soon ordered the removal of ''L'ange du mal'', and the building committee passed the commission for the pulpit sculpture to Guillaume Geefs, whose version was installed at the cathedral permanently in 1848.<ref>Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Fabritius [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/fabritiusweb/FullBB.csp?WebAction=ShowFullBB&RequestId=68766_2&Profile=Default&OpacLanguage=fre&NumberToRetrieve=10&StartValue=85&WebPageNr=1&SearchTerm1=GEEFSJOSEPH%20.2.3570&SearchT1=&Index1=Index24b&SearchMethod=Find_1&ItemNr=5 catalogue], from Francisca Vandepitte, ''Le Romantisme en Belgique. Entre réalités, rêves et souvenirs (exposition): Bruxelles, Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique; Espace Culturel ING; Musée Antoine Wiertz, 18.03–31.07.2005'' (Brussels, 2005), p. 109.</ref>
== Reception of Joseph Geefs' ''L'ange du mal'' == Joseph exhibited his sculpture at [[Antwerp]] in 1843, along with four other works: a sculpture group called ''The Dream'', and the individual statues ''St. [[Philomena]]'', ''Faithful Love'', and ''The Fisherman's Orphan''.<ref>Marchal, ''Annuaire'' p. 315.</ref> Known both as ''L'ange du mal'' (''Angel of Evil'') and ''Le génie du mal'', the controversial piece was later received into the collections of the [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], where it has remained as of 2009.<ref>Joseph's work is often referred to as ''L'ange du mal'', but its formal title according to the Royal Museums' online 19th-century sculpture [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/fr/frames/F_sculpture.html catalogue] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322045449/http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/FR/frames/F_sculpture.html |date=2009-03-22 }} remains ''Le génie du mal''. The common title ''L'ange du mal'' is used in this article to distinguish Joseph's sculpture from that of Guillaume.</ref>
Despite or because of the controversy, Joseph's work was admired at the highest levels of society. [[Charles Frederick, Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach|Charles Frederick]], [[Grand duchy|Grand Duke]] of [[Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach|Saxe-Weimar]], ordered a marble replica as early as 1842.<ref>As of 2009, this copy remains in the collections of the [[Goethe]] [[Goethe National Museum|National Museum]], [[Weimar]].</ref> The deracinated original was purchased for 3,000 [[Dutch guilder|florins]] by [[William II of the Netherlands|William II, King of the Netherlands]], and was dispersed with the rest of his collection in 1850 following his death. In 1854, the artist sold a [[plaster cast]] of the statue to [[Bernhard von Lindenau|Baron Bernard August von Lindenau]],<ref>Royal Museums, Fabritius description; Edmond Marchal, ''La sculpture et les chefs-d'œuvre de l'orfèvrerie belges'' (Brussels, 1895), p. 684 [https://books.google.com/books?id=fCkEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA684&dq=%22Le+génie+du+Mal%22+inauthor:Marchal&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Michael Palmer ''et al.'', ''500 chefs-d'oeuvre de l'art belge du XV<sup>e</sup> siècle à nos jours'' (Éditions Racine, n.d.), p. 203 [https://books.google.com/books?id=eIhHTre5wYoC&pg=PT206&dq=%22Le+génie+du+Mal%22+intitle:500+intitle:chefs&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> the German statesman, astronomer, and art collector for whom the [[Lindenau-Museum Altenburg]] is named.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lindenau-museum.de/museum/index.html |title=Das Lindenau-Museum Altenburg |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420172857/http://www.lindenau-museum.de/museum/index.html |archivedate=April 20, 2009 }}</ref> The success of the work elevated Joseph Geefs to the top tier of sculptors in his day.<ref>"Une légtimate admiration accueillit cette œuvre. Le plus grand succès répondit à l'attente de l'artiste et plaça celui-ci au premier rang des statuaires de ce temps": Marchal, ''Annuaire'' p. 315.</ref>
''L'ange du mal'' is among six statues featured in a painting by [[Pierre Langlet]], ''The Sculpture Hall of the Brussels Museum'' (''Salle de sculpture du Musée de Bruxelles'', 1882), along with ''Love and Malice'' by another of the six Geefs sculptor-brothers, Jean.<ref>Françoise Roberts-Jones-Popelier, ''Chronique d'un musée: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts, Bruxelles'' (Pierre Mardaga, 1987), p. 31 [https://books.google.com/books?id=fXjRc4yYNukC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=Geefs+%22l'ange+du+mal%22&source=bl&ots=BIcV1lrjSm&sig=aAPWtgr24fiqCliOw-0QG7U5Cgc&hl=en&ei=UTL6Sb_GB5LQMu643NQE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#PPA31,M1 online], with the painting reproduced on p. 32. ''Love and Malice'' by Jean Geefs may be viewed [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/fabritiusweb/FullBB.csp?WebAction=ShowFullBB&RequestId=68766_2&Profile=Default&OpacLanguage=fre&NumberToRetrieve=10&StartValue=81&WebPageNr=1&SearchTerm1=GEEFSJEAN%20.2.3418&SearchT1=&Index1=Index24b&SearchMethod=Find_1&ItemNr=1 online.]</ref>
''L'ange du mal'' was not uniformly admired even as a work of art. When it appeared in an 1862 international exhibition, the reviewer criticized Geefs' work as "gentle and languid" and lacking in "muscle", "a devil sick... : the sting of Satan is taken out."<ref>J. Beavington Atkinson, "Modern Sculpture of All Nations in the Exhibition," ''The Art Journal Illustrated Catalogue of the International Exhibition 1862'' p. 318.</ref>
=== 'This devil is too sublime' === [[File:L'ange du mal (Joseph Geefs) cropped.jpg|thumb|left|175px|'''''L'ange du mal''''' (1842) by Joseph Geefs]] [[File:Joseph Geefs.jpg|thumb|125px|'''Joseph Geefs''']]
Other than the [[Vesper bat|vespertilionid]] wings, the fallen angel of Joseph Geefs<ref>In Dutch and German sources, the artist's name may appear as Jozef Geefs.</ref> takes a completely human form, made manifest by its [[Depictions of nudity|artistic near-nudity]]. A languid scarf skims the groin, the hips are bared, and the open thighs form an avenue that leads to shadow.<ref>For better angles on the compositional treatment of the drapery in relation to the groin, see [https://books.google.com/books?id=eIhHTre5wYoC&pg=PT206&lpg=PT206&dq=%22du+mal%22+%22joseph+geefs%22&source=bl&ots=YP_hYHDnT5&sig=zypV76xNNkiABUufYUcfUC7kIpU&hl=en&ei=dOT1Sd6XI4ieMo_jgK4P&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=21 ''500 chefs''] and [http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2296/2455381558_4b740d4475.jpg?v=0 detail.] More information available on the photo [https://www.flickr.com/photos/pikimota/2455381558 detail.]</ref> The serpentine curve of waist and hip is given compositional play in relation to the wing-arcs. The torso is fit but youthful; smooth and graceful, almost [[androgynous]]. The angel's expression has been described as "serious, somber, even fierce,"<ref>''500 chefs-d'oeuvre de l'art belge'' p. 203. The angel's facial expression may not be apparent in the photograph that illustrates this article; view [https://books.google.com/books?id=eIhHTre5wYoC&pg=PT206&lpg=PT206&dq=%22du+mal%22+%22joseph+geefs%22&source=bl&ots=YP_hYHDnT5&sig=zypV76xNNkiABUufYUcfUC7kIpU&hl=en&ei=dOT1Sd6XI4ieMo_jgK4P&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=21 another angle.]</ref> and the cast-down gaze directs the viewer's eye along the body and thighs to the parted knees. The most obvious satanic element in addition to the wings is the [[Serpents in the Bible|snake]] uncoiling across the base of the rock. ''L'ange du mal'' has been called "one of the most disturbing works of its time."<ref>Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, 19th-century sculpture collection [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/EN/frames/F_sculpture.html online introduction.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624003318/http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/EN/frames/F_sculpture.html |date=2009-06-24 }}</ref>
Joseph's sculptures are "striking for their perfect finish and grace, their elegant and even poetic line," but while exhibiting these qualities in abundance, ''L'ange du mal'' is exceptional within the artist's body of work for its subject matter:<ref>''500 chefs-d'oeuvre de l'art belge'' p. 203.</ref>
{{quote|It compellingly illustrates the Romantic era's attraction to darkness and the abyss, and the rehabilitation of the rebellious fallen angel. The [[bat (animal)|chiropteral]] wings, far from inspiring revulsion, form a frame that enhances the beauty of a youthful body.<ref>"Elle illustre en effet l'attrait de l'époque romantique pour les ténèbres, l'abîme, et sa réhabilitation de l'ange rebelle déchu. Les ailes de chéiroptère loin d'inspirer la révulsion, forme un écrin mettant en valeur la beauté d' un corps juvénile": Vicky Chris, [http://es.treklens.com/gallery/Europe/Belgium/photo425244.htm TrekLens] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115211210/http://es.treklens.com/gallery/Europe/Belgium/photo425244.htm |date=2017-11-15 }}, with a side view of the photo showing the exposure of the hip.</ref>}}
As a sort of "winged [[Adonis]]",<ref>Royal Museums of Fine Arts, Fabritius [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/fabritiusweb/FullBB.csp?WebAction=ShowFullBB&RequestId=68766_2&Profile=Default&OpacLanguage=fre&NumberToRetrieve=10&StartValue=85&WebPageNr=1&SearchTerm1=GEEFSJOSEPH%20.2.3570&SearchT1=&Index1=Index24b&SearchMethod=Find_1&ItemNr=5 ''Le génie du mal''.]</ref> the fallen angel can be seen as developing from Geefs' early nude ''Adonis allant à la chasse avec son chien'' (''Adonis Goes Hunting with His Hound'').<ref>Royal Museums of Fine Arts, Fabritius [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/fabritiusweb/FullBB.csp?WebAction=ShowFullBB&RequestId=68766_2&Profile=Default&OpacLanguage=fre&NumberToRetrieve=10&StartValue=83&WebPageNr=1&SearchTerm1=GEEFSJOSEPH%20.2.3567&SearchT1=&Index1=Index24b&SearchMethod=Find_1&ItemNr=3 ''Adonis allant à la chasse''.]</ref> The composition of ''L'ange du mal'' has been compared to that of [[Jean-Jacques Feuchère]]'s small bronze ''Satan'' (1833), with Geefs' angel notably "less diabolic".<ref>Didier Rykner, review of the exhibition "Le romantisme en Belgique. Entre réalités, rêves et souvenirs," 18 March–31 July 2005 at the [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], Brussels, and Espace Culturel ING, ''La Tribune de l'Art'', 13 April 2005 [http://www.latribunedelart.com/Expositions_2005/Romantisme_Belgique_234.htm online.] Feuchère's ''Satan'' exists in multiple copies. The 1833 original of ''Satan'' held by the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]] is not on public display, but may be viewed [http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=2349 online.] As of 30 April 2009, an 1836 version was on public display at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]; it may be viewed among the museum's [http://collectionsonline.lacma.org/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33014;type=101 online collections.] For the version at the Royal Museum in Brussels, search Feuchère in the museum's [http://www.opac-fabritius.be/fr/F_database.htm database.]</ref> The humanizing of Lucifer through nudity is characteristic also of the Italian sculptor [[Costantino Corti]]'s colossal work, executed a few years after the Geefs' versions. Corti depicts his Lucifer as frontally nude, though shielded discreetly by the pinnacle of rock he straddles, and framed with the feathered wings of his angel origin.<ref>See article on [[Costantino Corti]] for an engraving of ''Lucifer''.</ref> {{Clear}}
==Chained genius== [[File:Lucifer of Liège (foot detail) by Viatour.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Detail of '''''Le génie du mal''''': chained ankle, tasted apple, broken sceptre ''(from photo by Luc Viatour)'']]
Without a statement from the artist, it can only be surmised that Guillaume Geefs sought to address specific criticisms leveled at his brother Joseph's work. Guillaume's ''génie'' shows less flesh, and is marked more strongly by satanic [[iconography]] as neither human nor angelic. Whether Guillaume succeeded in removing the "seductive" elements may be a matter of individual perception.
[[File:Lucifer of Liège (horns detail) Viatour.jpg|thumb|Horns, and a collocation of human and animal anatomy (detail)]] [[File:Horned Moses (detail).jpg|thumb|[[Moses#Figurative art|Horned Moses]]]]Guillaume shifts the direction of the fallen angel's gaze so that it leads away from the body, and his Lucifer's knees are drawn together protectively. The drapery hangs from behind the right shoulder, pools on the right side, and undulates thickly over the thighs, concealing the hips, not quite covering the navel. At the same time, the flesh that remains exposed is resolutely modeled, particularly in the upper arms, pectorals, and calves, to reveal a more defined, muscled masculinity. The uplifted right arm allows the artist to explore the patterned tensions of the [[serratus anterior muscle]]s, and the gesture and the angle of the head suggest that the ''génie'' is warding off "divine chastisement".<ref>Geuzaine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''.</ref>
===Symbols of Lucifer=== Guillaume added several details to enhance the Luciferian iconography and the theme of punishment: at the angel's feet, the dropped "[[forbidden fruit]]", an [[Apple (symbolism)|apple]] with bite marks, along with the broken-off tip of the sceptre, the stellar [[finial]] of which marks [[Lucifer#Latin name for the Morning Star|Lucifer as the Morning Star of classical tradition]]. The [[Nail (anatomy)|nails]] are narrow and elongated, like talons.<ref>Geuzaine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''.</ref>
A pair of horns may be intended to further dehumanize the figure, while introducing another note of [[ambiguity]]. Horns are animalistic markers of the satanic or demonic, but in a parallel tradition of religious iconography, "horns" represent points of light. Gods from antiquity who personify celestial phenomena such as the Sun or stars are crowned with rays, and some depictions of [[Moses]], the most famous being that of [[Michelangelo]], are carved with "horns" similar to those of Geefs' Lucifer; see [[Moses (Michelangelo)|Horned Moses]].
===Promethean Lucifer=== [[File:Prometheus Bound (Paul Bouré).jpg|thumb|left|230px|A bronze ''Prometheus Bound'' (1845) by Belgian artist [[Paul Bouré]], who once studied with Guillaume Geefs]] But the most apparent departure from ''L'ange du mal'' is the placing of Lucifer in <!--the following link to a disambiguation page is deliberate, as a full range of meaning should apply-->[[bondage (disambiguation)|bondage]], with his right ankle and left wrist chained. In 19th-century reinterpretations of [[Greek mythology|ancient Greek]] and [[Christian mythology|Christian myths]], Lucifer was often cast as a [[Prometheus|Promethean]] figure, drawing on a tradition that the fallen angel was chained in [[Hell]] just as the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]] had been chained and [[Torture#Torture in the past|tortured]] on the rock by [[Zeus]]: "The same [[Prometheus]] who is taken as an [[Analogue (literature)|analogue]] of the [[Crucifixion of Jesus|crucified Christ]] is regarded also as a type of Lucifer," wrote [[Harold Bloom]] in remarks on [[Mary Shelley]]'s 19th-century classic ''[[Frankenstein]]'', subtitled ''The Modern Prometheus''.<ref>[[Harold Bloom]], 1965 afterword republished in the Signet Classic 2000 edition of [[Mary Shelley]]'s ''[[Frankenstein]]'', p. 201 [https://books.google.com/books?id=gBJbpHyFf7MC&pg=PA201&dq=%22The+same+Prometheus+who+is+taken+as+an+analogue+of+the+crucified+Christ+is+regarded+also+as+a+type+of+Lucifer%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] The literature on the connection between Lucifer and Prometheus made in 19th-century art and literature is vast. See, for instance, discussion of [[Goethe]] and the [[Gnostic]] Lucifer in Steven M. Wasserstrom, ''Religion after Religion: Gershom Scholem, Mircea Eliade, and Henry Corbin at Eranos'' (Princeton University Press, 1999), p. 210ff. [https://books.google.com/books?id=RvuHVggCA-IC&pg=PA210&dq=%22Prometheus,+Corbin+tells+us,+was+also+the+archetype+for+the+Man+of+Light,+the+gnostic+Lucifer%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] Discussion of Lucifer in [[August Strindberg|Strindberg]]'s ''Coram Populo'' in Harry Gilbert Carlson, ''Out of Inferno: Strindberg's Reawakening as an Artist'' (University of Washington Press, 1996), pp. 103–106 [https://books.google.com/books?id=k8KZpjTVuJQC&pg=PA103&dq=%22coram+populo+medieval+pastiche%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] The association of Lucifer with [[Prometheus]] and other mythological figures such as [[Loki]] was a particular feature of 19th-century [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophy]] and the esoteric writings of [[Madame Blavatsky|H.P. Blavatsky]]; see ''The Secret Doctrine'' (London, 1893), vol. 2, p. 296 [https://books.google.com/books?id=zCcVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA296&dq=%22Hence+Loki+is+identical+with+Lucifer%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=1&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] The Promethean qualities of Lucifer are a standard theme in [[John Milton|Milton]] studies; see ''[[Lucifer and Prometheus]]'' for a perspective on ''[[Paradise Lost]]''.</ref> In [[Alexander Haggerty Krappe|A.H. Krappe]]'s [[folklore|folkloric]] typology, Lucifer conforms to a type that includes Prometheus and the Germanic [[Loki]].<ref>Lois Bragg, ''Oedipus Borealis: The Aberrant Body in Old Icelandic Myth and Saga'' (Fairleigh Dickinson University Press, 2004), pp. 132–133, particularly point 7 [https://books.google.com/books?id=8GLeJQbNmCAC&pg=PA132&dq=%22By+comparing+European+and+Christian+mythologies%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
Guillaume Geefs' addition of fetters, with the swagged chain replacing the sneering serpent in Joseph's version, displays the angel's defeat in pious adherence to Christian ideology. At the same time, the titanic struggle of the tortured genius to free himself from [[metaphor]]ical chains was a motif of Romanticism,<ref>Pam Morris, ''Realism'' (Routledge, 2003), p. 52 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MFAW6dh24ZwC&pg=PA52&dq=%22titanic+struggle%22+ROmanticism+OR+Romantic&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA52,M1 online.]</ref> which took hold in Belgium in the wake of the [[Belgian Revolution|Revolution of 1830]]. The Belgians had just secured their own "liberation"; over the ensuing two decades, there had been a craze for public sculpture, by the Geefs brothers and others, that celebrated the leaders of independence. The magnificently human figure of the iconic rebel who failed might have been expected to elicit a complex or ambivalent response.<ref>Royal Museum of Fine Arts, [http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/EN/frames/F_sculpture.html "Romanticism."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624003318/http://www.fine-arts-museum.be/site/EN/frames/F_sculpture.html |date=2009-06-24 }}</ref> The suffering face of the ''génie'', stripped of the angry hauteur of ''L'ange du mal'', has been read as expressing remorse and despair; a tear slips from the left eye.<ref>Geuzine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''.</ref> {{Clear}}
==Sister of angels== [[File:Lucifer of Liège (tear detail) LucViatour.jpg|thumb|The tear of Lucifer (detail of ''Le génie du mal'')]] In a 1990 essay, Belgian art historian [[:fr:Jacques Lennep|Jacques Van Lennep]] discussed how the conception of ''Le génie du mal'' was influenced by [[Alfred de Vigny]]'s long philosophical poem ''[[Éloa, ou La sœur des anges]]'' ("Eloa, or the Sister of Angels"), published in 1824, which explored the possibility of Lucifer's redemption through love.<ref>[http://www.lennep.be/principale.htm Jacques Van Lennep] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531121201/http://www.lennep.be/principale.htm |date=2009-05-31 }}, ''La Sculpture belge au xixe siècle, exposition organisée à Bruxelles du 5 octobre au 15 décembre 1990, La Générale de banque, Bruxelles'' (Exhibition catalogue, 1990), as cited by Geuzaine and Creusen, ''Vers la modernité''. Although in origin Lucifer and Satan may be distinct beings, ''Eloa'' draws on a literary tradition that [[conflation|conflates]] the two figures. {{cite web |url=http://www.lennep.be/principale.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531121201/http://www.lennep.be/principale.htm |archivedate=May 31, 2009 |df= }}</ref> In this "lush and lyrical" narrative poem, Lucifer sets out to seduce the beautiful Eloa, an angel born from a tear shed by [[Christ]] at the death of [[Lazarus of Bethany|Lazarus]]. The Satanic lover is "literally a handsome devil, physically dashing, intellectually agile, irresistibly charismatic in speech and manner": in short, a [[Romantic hero]]. "Since you are so beautiful," the naïve Eloa says, "you are no doubt good."
Lucifer declares that "I am he whom one loves and does not know,"<ref>In French, ''Je suis celui qu'on aime et qu'on ne connaît pas.''</ref> and says he weeps for the powerless and grants them the occasional reprieve of delight or oblivion. Despite Eloa's attempt to reconcile him with God, Lucifer cannot set aside his destructive pride. In the end, Eloa's love condemns her to Hell with Lucifer, and his triumph over her only brings him sadness.<ref>Elizabeth Cheresh Allen, ''A Fallen Idol Is Still a God: [[Mikhail Lermontov|Lermontov]] and the Quandaries of Cultural Transition'' (Stanford University Press, 2007), pp. 89–90 [https://books.google.com/books?id=C0SsAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA89&dq=%22One+of+these+incarnations+appeared+in+Alfred+de+Vigny%27s+Eloa%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Miriam Van Scott, ''The Encyclopedia of Hell'' (Macmillan, 1999), p. 103 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I9QNUhT4besC&pg=PA103&lpg=PA103&dq=%22sœur+des+anges%22+%22Alfred+de+Vigny%22&source=bl&ots=z0LByqY6Bw&sig=Ns9vq2M-OuCYLr0u65KW2bSS41U&hl=en&ei=QT_-SaKmFYieMtiwoLEE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=16 online.]</ref>
==''Himmelsweg''== :''A version of'' Himmelsweg ''by Jacques Charlier may be viewed'' In 1986, the Belgian artist [[:fr:Jacques Charlier|Jacques Charlier]] made ''Le génie du mal'' a focal point of his [[Installation art|installation]] ''Himmelsweg'' ("The Road to Paradise"). A framed photograph of the sculpture hangs over a slender pedestal table that is draped with a black cloth. A transparent case on the table contains three books: a [[Carmelites|Carmelite]] study on the subject of [[Satan]], a scientific treatise on [[Earth's atmosphere|air]], and a memorial of the [[History of the Jews in Belgium|Belgian Jews]] killed at [[Auschwitz]]. On the lower shelf of the table are [[shackles]].
Charlier has described his use of ''Le génie du mal'' as "a Romantic image that speaks to us of [[seduction]], [[evil]], and the [[sin]] of forgetting." The German title of the work refers to the [[Nazi]] euphemism or "cold joke" for the access ramp that led to the [[Gas chamber#Nazi Germany|gas chambers]]: "The Road to Paradise leads to Hell; [[Fall of Man|the Fall]] is so close to [[Salvation#Redemption|redemption]]."<ref>Nadja Vilenne galerie, ''[http://www.nadjavilenne.com/charlier_esprit.htm Himmelsweg] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704054747/http://www.nadjavilenne.com/charlier_esprit.htm |date=2008-07-04 }}'', with artist interview conducted by R.Vandersanden; gallery news blogged by Jean-Michel Botquin, English [http://blog.nadjavilenne.com/dotclear/index.php?2008/03 version], 13 March 2008. On the word ''Himmelweg'' or ''Himmelsweg'', see Carrie Supple, ''From Prejudice to Genocide: Learning about the Holocaust'' (Trentham Books, 1993, 2nd ed.), p. 167 [https://books.google.com/books?id=cCx8xNkj20MC&pg=PA167&dq=%22the+Germans+called+the+path+leading+to+the+gas+chamber+Himmel-weg%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; [[Kate Millett]], ''The Politics of Cruelty: An Essay on the Literature of Political Imprisonment'' (W.W. Norton, 1995), p. 59 [https://books.google.com/books?id=i-QQAhSRhjAC&pg=PA59&dq=%22the+Himmelsweg+or+road+to+heaven%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; see also "The Cold Joke and Desecration" in [[Jonathan Glover]], ''Humanity: A Moral History of the Twentieth Century'' (Yale University Press, 2000), p. 341 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xtqFJVhmuowC&pg=PA340&dq=%22The+Cold+Joke+and+Desecration%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA341,M1 online.]</ref>
==Alternative religious veneration== [[File:Chaire Cathédrale Liège 240809 06.jpg|thumb|left|The work in its architectural setting at the cathedral in Liège]] [[File:Serpent detail L'ange du mal (Joseph Geefs).jpg|thumb|90px|Serpent's head detail from Joseph Guillaume's ''L'ange du mal'']] ''Le génie du mal'' sometimes appears on [[blog]]s, [[Internet forum]]s, and other [[website]]s that are devoted to alternative religious practices such as [[Satanism]] and [[Luciferianism]].<ref>Examples (all retrieved 4 May 2009) include [http://paganspace.ning.com/forum/topics/1342861:Topic:1600469?page=9&commentId=1342861%3AComment%3A2028941&x=1#1342861Comment2028941 PaganSpace.net]; [http://205.155.133.191/~langhoffti/Luciferian.html Luciferianism]{{dead link|date=February 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}; [http://satanists.tribe.net/photos/6965d0ad-76c2-4d1d-b554-924f1ad4e045 Satanist Tribe.net] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724112618/http://satanists.tribe.net/photos/6965d0ad-76c2-4d1d-b554-924f1ad4e045 |date=2011-07-24 }}; [http://satanists.tribenetwork.com/ Satanists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223003800/http://satanists.tribenetwork.com/ |date=2012-02-23 }}.</ref> A travel writer has observed that in the 21st century, the sculpture
{{quote|is so successful that [[Satanists]] regularly come to meditate at its feet: enough to incur [[damnation]], indeed; its [[excommunication]] is being considered.<ref>Georges Rouzeau, "Spotlight on Liège," [https://archive.is/20080515044706/http://www.viamichelin.co.uk/viamichelin/gbr/tpl/mag5/art20080315/htm/tour-visit-liege.htm Via Michelin online.]</ref>}}
==Selected bibliography== *Soo Yang Geuzaine et Alexia Creusen, "Guillaume Geefs: ''Le Génie du Mal'' (1848) à la cathédrale Saint-Paul de Liège," ''Vers la modernité.
