{{Infobox organization | name = Rock the Vote | logo = Rock the Vote logo.png | logo_size = 200px | founded_date = 1990 in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]<ref name=hard>{{cite news|last1=Duhigg|first1=Charles|title=Rock the Vote Is Stuck in a Hard Place|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/feb/07/business/fi-rockthevote7|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=February 7, 2006}}</ref> | location = [[Washington, D.C.]], United States | area_served = United States | focus = [[Voter registration]], [[Youth vote|youth voting]] | method = Online mobilization, field organizing, entertainment community | homepage = {{URL|http://rockthevote.com}} }}
'''Rock the Vote''' is a [[non-profit organization]], progressive-aligned group in the [[United States]] whose stated mission is "to engage and build the political power of young people."<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.rockthevote.com/about-us/|publisher=Rock The Vote|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
The organization was founded in 1990 by Virgin Records America Co-Chairman Jeff Ayeroff, to encourage young people to vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Contrera|first1=Jessica|title=Lil Jon and Lena Dunham team up to take on what Madonna and Chuck D pioneered|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2014/10/07/lil-jon-and-lena-dunham-team-up-to-take-on-what-madonna-and-chuck-d-pioneered/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> It is geared toward increasing voter turnout among voters ages 18 to 24.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lurie|first1=Stephen|title=Millennial turnout is crucial. Too bad pols have no idea what young people care about.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2014/10/31/millennial-turnout-is-crucial-too-bad-pols-have-no-idea-what-young-people-care-about/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 31, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Beaucar Vlahos|first1=Kelley|title=Youth Activist Groups Target Voter Turnout|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/12/11/youth-activist-groups-target-voter-turnout/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Fox News|date=December 11, 2003}}</ref> Rock the Vote is known for its celebrity spokespeople and its partnership with [[MTV]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Benjamin|title=Rock the Vote Gets Angry in New Ads|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/rock-vote-angry-ads/story?id=25930607|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=October 3, 2014}}</ref>
==History== Rock the Vote was founded in 1990 by Jeff Ayeroff with Virgin America co Chair Jordan Harris and Virgin Executive Beverly Lund. Later they hired Jodi Uttal and then [[Steve Barr (educational innovator)|Steve Barr]], a campaign worker and political fundraiser, who became "co-founders" for their contribution to Rock the Vote. Rock the Vote supported the [[National Voter Registration Act of 1993]], commonly referred to as the "motor voter" bill, which expanded access to voter registration. It was signed into law by [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]]. The law requires state governments to offer voter registration opportunities to any eligible person who applies for or renews a driver's license or public assistance.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cloward|first1=Richard|last2=Pivin|first2=Frances Scott|title=Why Americans Still Don't Vote: And why Politicians Want it that Way|date=2000|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=9780807004494|page=247}}</ref>
In 1996, Rock the Vote created the first telephone voter registration system, 1-800-REGISTER, followed by the first online voter-registration system, NetVote, later that year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flanagin|first1=Jake|title=Here’s Why You Should Turn Out and Rock the Vote|url=http://op-talk.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/09/heres-why-you-should-turn-out-and-rock-the-vote/?_r=0|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=October 9, 2014}}</ref>
"We supported Rock the Vote," said [[Radiohead]]'s [[Thom Yorke]], "but – because of the way the whole political system works – it does seem rather odd to be choosing between one unworkable, outdated system and another. We need to go beyond that – because, at the moment, it's just [[Cowboys and Indians (disambiguation)|Cowboys and Indians]]."<ref>{{cite journal|first= Caitlin |last= [[Caitlin Moran|Moran]] |title= Everything was just fear. |magazine= ''[[Select (magazine)|Select]]'' |date= July 1997 |page= 86}}</ref>
With [[CNN]], Rock the Vote organized "America Rocks the Vote," a 2003 Democratic presidential candidates forum at [[Faneuil Hall]] in Boston.<ref>{{cite news|title=CNN, Rock the Vote to co-sponsor Democratic candidate forum|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/ALLPOLITICS/10/01/elec04.prez.rock.vote/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=CNN|date=October 1, 2003}}</ref>
Rock the Vote has expressed support for a [[public health insurance option]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mattera|first1=Jason|title=Obama Zombies: How the Liberal Machine Brainwashed My Generation|date=2010|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439172094|page=154}}</ref> It signed on to [[Health Care for America NOW!]], a progressive political coalition that supported passage of the [[Affordable Care Act]]. In 2009, Rock the Vote ran a campaign encouraging people to refuse to have sex with those who opposed what they regarded as a reform of American health care.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rock the Vote Asks Supporters to Withhold Sex to Pass Health Care Reform|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/12/21/rock-vote-asks-supporters-withhold-sex-pass-health-care-reform/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Fox News|date=December 21, 2009}}</ref>
During the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]], Rock the Vote drew criticism from [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] officials such as [[Republican National Committee]] chairman [[Ed Gillespie]] for sending a mock [[military draft|draft]] notice to over 600,000 e-mail addresses. The message included the words "[[Selective Service System]]" and read "You are hereby ordered for induction into the Armed Forces of the United States, and to report to a polling place near you" on November 2, ([[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]]). The Rock the Vote logo and a facsimile of [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary]] [[Donald Rumsfeld]]'s signature appeared at the bottom of the message. In addition, Rock the Vote created [[public service announcement]]s featuring the subject of the draft.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rock The Vote, MTV Irk GOP|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/65818/rock-the-vote-mtv-irk-gop|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Billboard Magazine|date=November 2, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sisto|first1=Christine|title=Rock the Democratic Vote|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/389978/rock-democratic-vote-christine-sisto|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=National Review|date=October 16, 2014}}</ref> Besides making the PSAs available to large cable systems, they also paid to run them on a random sample of small cable systems where they could measure the effects. Turnout was three percentage points higher among 18-19-year olds in these sample areas than in the control group covered by other similar small cable systems; there was less effect above age 22.<ref name="vavreck">{{Cite journal |last=Green |first=Donald P. |last2=Vavreck |first2=Lynn |date=2008 |title=Analysis of Cluster-Randomized Experiments: A Comparison of Alternative Estimation Approaches |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Donald_Green4/publication/31382310_Analysis_of_Cluster-Randomized_Experiments_A_Comparison_of_Alternative_Estimation_Approaches/links/00b4951f9a12acc282000000.pdf |journal=Political Analysis |language=en |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=138–152 |doi=10.1093/pan/mpm025 |issn=1047-1987}}</ref><ref name="green" />
According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Rock the Vote experienced financial problems in the aftermath of the 2004 election. It emerged from the election $700,000 in debt, and its president resigned in the summer of 2005 "amid disagreements about the organization's direction."<ref name=hard/>
In 2008, Rock the Vote ran the largest non-partisan youth voter registration drive in the nation's history by getting 2.6 million young voters registered.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGuirt|first1=Mary|title=Young Black Turnout a Record in 2008 Election|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=8140030|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=July 21, 2009}}</ref>
In November 2012 and 2013 Rock the Vote experimented with Facebook ads to encourage voter turnout by telling people the number of days remaining until the election and which of their friends "liked" the countdown. The ads were shown to over 400,000 adults, randomly selected from a base over 800,000. Rock the Vote had helped many of them register. The ads did not increase turnout in the experimental group, compared to the control group who did not get the ads.<ref name="green">{{Cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/922072845 |title=Get out the vote : how to increase voter turnout |last=Green |first=Donald P. |isbn=081572568X |edition= Third |location=Washington, D.C. |pages=97–98, 101, 120–121 |oclc=922072845}}</ref> In 2012 they also experimented with text message reminders to 180,000 people who had provided their mobile numbers. Texts the day before the election raised turnout six tenths of a percentage point, while texts on election day lowered turnout.<ref name="green" />
In advance of the 2014 elections, Rock the Vote released a video titled "Turn Out For What." It was a parody of [[Lil Jon]] and [[DJ Snake]]'s song "[[Turn Down for What]]".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kreps|first1=Daniel|title=Lena Dunham, Lil Jon Team for Rock the Vote's 'Turn Out for What' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/lena-dunham-lil-jon-team-for-rock-the-votes-turn-out-for-what-video-20141007|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> The video sought to encourage youth voter turnout and featured [[reproductive rights]], [[marijuana legalization]], [[global warming]], [[LGBT rights]], student debt, [[gun control]] and [[deforestation]] as reasons why young people might want to vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peligri|first1=Justin|title=Lil Jon and Lena Dunham 'Turn Out' in new Rock The Vote video|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/07/politics/new-rock-the-vote-video/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=CNN|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> The video was criticized by some Republicans who said it had a disproportionate representation of liberal issues.<ref>{{cite news|title='Rock the Vote' celebrities called out for not voting in last mid-term election|url=http://abc7.com/politics/rock-the-vote-celebrities-called-out-for-not-voting/380155/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=November 4, 2014}}</ref> The video was also criticized because several of the celebrities who appeared in it, including [[Lena Dunham]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Natasha Lyonne]] and [[Darren Criss]], had not voted in the previous midterm election.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lombardi|first1=Ken|title=Some Rock The Vote midterm PSA stars didn't vote in last midterm|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/rock-the-vote-midterm-psa-celebrities-didnt-vote-in-last-midterm/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=CBS News|date=November 3, 2014}}</ref>
The day after the [[2016 U.S. presidential election]], Rock the Vote President and Executive Director Carolyn DeWitt issued a statement on behalf of the organization expressing disappointment with the election of [[Donald Trump]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] congressional victories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@RockTheVote/rock-the-vote-responds-to-2016-presidential-election-results-fac7a420c815|title=Rock the Vote Responds to 2016 Presidential Election Results|first=Rock the|last=Vote|date=9 November 2016|publisher=Medium}}</ref>
==Democracy Class== Rock the Vote: Democracy Class is a program put on by Rock the Vote. It is designed to educate high school students about voting, elections and governance. The [[nonpartisan]] lesson plan uses music, pop culture, video, classroom discussion and a [[mock election]] to teach young people the skills to navigate the [[elections]] process and engage as active citizens.<ref name=nation>{{cite news|last1=Rothberg|first1=Peter|title=Democracy Class|url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/166987/democracy-class|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=The Nation|date=March 22, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ramesh|first1=Indu|title=Rock the Vote campaigns to spark young voters|url=http://www.dukechronicle.com/articles/2010/08/27/rock-vote-campaigns-spark-young-voters#.VNU61sYhwt8|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=Duke Chronicle|date=August 26, 2010}}</ref> On Democracy Day 2011, teachers in all 50 states committed to teaching Democracy Class in more than 1,100 classrooms.<ref name=nation/> High school students in Democracy Classes participate in mobile polls that assess their viewpoints on public policy issues.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Lauren|title=Mobile is key to connecting with young voters: Rock the Vote|url=http://www.mobilemarketer.com/cms/news/strategy/12247.html|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=Mobile Marketer|date=March 2, 2012}}</ref>

{{Infobox orchestra | name = Russian Symphony Orchestra Society | image = Russian Symphony Orchestra 7 Jan 1904 ad.jpg | caption = Advertisement for the orchestra's first performance on January 7, 1904 | alt = Newspaper clipping giving the venue as "Cooper Union Auditorium 8th St. and 4th Av." | location = New York City | founded = {{Start date|1903}} | disbanded = 1922<ref>According to [http://www.stokowski.org/Principal_Musicians_Russian_Symphony_of_NY.htm Russian Symphony Orchestra of New York: A Chronological Listing], stokowski.org (accessed 2015-09-29), their last annual season of New York concerts was 1919, but they continued to tour in the summer until 1922.</ref> }}
The '''Russian Symphony Orchestra Society''' (also known simply as the '''Russian Symphony Orchestra''') was founded in {{start date|1903}} in [[New York City]]<ref>"Of Music and Musicians: Plans Outlined for the Coming Worcester Festival—Russian Symphony Society Incorporated—Notes Concerning Coming Events of Importance", ''New York Times'', 9 September 1903, p. 21.</ref><ref name=Slatkin>Leonard Slatkin, ''Conducting Business: Unveiling the Mystery Behind the Maestro'' (2012), Amadeus Press, p. 32. {{ISBN|1574672045}}. Accessed [https://books.google.com/books?id=K7os-1XoxAYC&pg=PT32&lpg=PT32#v=onepage&q&f=false on Google Books].</ref> by [[Modest Altschuler]], and functioned for fifteen years.<ref name=Slatkin/>
[[Oscar Levant]] described the orchestra as having constituted "a school for [[concertmaster]]s"; among its members were [[Frederic Fradkin]] (concertmaster of the [[Boston Symphony]]), [[Maximilian Pilzer]] (concertmaster of the [[New York Philharmonic]]), [[Ilya Skolnik]] (concertmaster of the [[Detroit Symphony]]), and [[Louis Edlin]] (concertmaster of the [[National Orchestral Association]]).<ref name=Levant>Oscar Levant, ''A Smattering of Ignorance'' (1940), Doubleday, pp. 27–28.</ref> Film music conductors [[Nikolai Sokoloff]], [[Nathaniel Shilkret]]<ref name=shilkret1>Shilkret, Nathaniel, ed. Shell, Niel and Barbara Shilkret, ''Nathaniel Shilkret: Sixty Years in the Music Business'', Scarecrow Press, Lanham, Maryland, 2005, p. 14. {{ISBN|0-8108-5128-8}}</ref> and [[Nat Finston]] were also Russian Symphony Orchestra alumni, as was trumpeter [[Harry Glantz]].<ref name=Levant /> The orchestra also formed the backbone of the '''New Music Society of America''', founded in December 1905.
They performed the New York premieres of numerous pieces by [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]], [[Igor Stravinsky]] and [[Alexander Scriabin]], including Stravinsky's first symphony (the [[Symphony in E-flat (Stravinsky)|Symphony in E-flat]]) and ''[[The Firebird]]''.<ref name=Levant />
==History==
===The early years=== The orchestra's debut public performance was at [[Cooper Union]] Hall on January 7, 1904, and, according to [[Leonard Slatkin]], featured works by [[Mikhail Glinka]], [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]], [[Henryk Wieniawski]], and the American premiere of Rachmaninoff's ''[[The Rock (Rachmaninoff)|The Rock]]''.<ref name=Slatkin /> However, the ''New York Times'' of January 3, 1904 lists the program as consisting of the Overture from Glinka's ''[[Ruslan and Lyudmila (opera)|Ruslan and Lyudmila]]'', a baritone aria from [[Alexander Borodin|Borodin]]'s ''[[Prince Igor]]'', an ''intermezzo'' from [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]], a Russian dance by [[Eduard Nápravník]] and the symphonic suite ''[[Scheherazade (Rimsky-Korsakov)|Scheherazade]]'' by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]];<ref>"Of Music and Musicians: …Russian Symphony Concerts…", ''New York Times'', 3 January 1904, p. 17.</ref> The ''Times'' of January 24 that same year mentions their second concert as including Wieniawski's ''Souvenir de Moscou''<ref>"Of Music and Musicians: …Russian Symphony Orchestra…", ''New York Times'', 24 January 1904, p. 17.</ref> and reviewing a later concert in the series mentions a performance of "'The Cliff' by Rachmaninoff," presumably the same piece as ''The Rock''.<ref>"Some Stageland Jottings: …Russian Symphony Orchestra…", ''New York Times'', 29 January 1904, p. 9.</ref>
For the 1904–1905 season, the orchestra, now expanded to 85 musicians,<ref>"Russian Symphony Orchestra, ''New York Times'', 20 November 1904, p. 9.</ref> performed six concerts at [[Carnegie Hall]], featuring a works by a broad range of Russian composers,<ref name="1905-11-05" /><ref>"Echoes from the World of Music: …Russian Symphony Orchestra…", ''New York Times'', 16 October 1904, p. SMA6.</ref> including a violin concerto by [[Julius Conus]].<ref>"Musical Notes", ''New York Times'', 30 October 1904, p. 8.</ref> The ''Times'' summarized the season as "resplendent with novelties,"<ref name="1905-04-02">"The Russian Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 2 April 1905, p. 9.</ref> and praised their "enthusiasm"<ref>"Musical Notes", ''New York Times'', 25 December 1904, p. 7.</ref> and the "absorbing interest" of their selected material,<ref name="1905-04-02" /> but was critical of the technical quality of their performances, particularly in comparison with their initial series of concerts at Cooper Union.<ref name="1905-04-02" /><ref>"The Russian Symphony", ''New York Times'', 22 January 1905, p. 5.</ref> That season, they were the first to use a [[celesta]] in concert performance in the United States.<ref>"Russian Symphony Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 4 January 1905, p. X4.</ref> Among many Russian pieces given their American premieres that season was Rimsky-Korsakov's ''[[The Tale of Tsar Saltan]]'';<ref>"Russian Symphony Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 15 January 1905, p. SMA4.</ref> the fourth concert of the season consisted entirely of works that had never before been presented in New York: [[Vasily Kalinnikov]]'s first symphony, [[Anton Arensky]]'s suite "Silhouettes", and excerpts from [[Modest Mussorgsky]]'s opera ''[[Khovanshchina]]''.<ref>"Russian Symphony Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 19 February 1905, p. X3.</ref>
The next year, their six Saturday night concerts at Carnegie Hall were supplemented by three "popular price" concerts there on Sunday afternoons.<ref name="1905-10-05">"A Season of Great Musical Activity… Russian Symphony Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 5 October 1905, p. X1.</ref> The orchestra formed a relationship with [[Vasily Safonov]].<ref>"Russian Symphony Concerts", ''New York Times'', 29 July 1905, p. 7.</ref> Rachmininoff was engaged as a guest conductor and piano soloist for concerts of his music performed on April 7–8, 1906, and Safonov's former pupil, pianist [[Joseph Lhévinne]], was brought over to make his American debut;<ref name="1905-10-05" /> both were in their early thirties at the time, as was composer [[Vasily Zolotarev]], whose ''Rhapsodie Hébraïque'' was also performed that season at Safonov's suggestion. ''Rhapsodie hébraïque'', presented on the last two days of 1905, was based on [[Secular Jewish music|secular Jewish melodies]] that the ''Times'' characterized as "the musical equivalent of [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]]."<ref>"Musical Notes: Concerts, Recitals and Church Choir News", ''New York Times'' , 17 December 1905, p. X1.</ref> Pianist [[Raoul Pugno]] also participated in the season as a soloist, playing Rachmaninoff's [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Rachmaninoff)|second piano concerto]].<ref name="1905-10-05">"The Russian Symphony", ''New York Times'', 12 November 1905, p. X1.</ref><ref>"Musical Notes: New York's Musical Public Increasing Rapidly", ''New York Times'', 29 October 1905, p. X1–X2.</ref> Now expanded to 90 musicians, the orchestra was becoming an increasingly professional affair with, as the ''Times'' put it, "soloists of the first rank."<ref name="1905-11-05">"Russian Symphony Orchestra, ''New York Times'', 5 November 1905, p. X1.</ref>
Another of those soloists was [[Giuseppe Campanari]], a [[baritone]] associated with the [[Metropolitan Opera]]. The chaos of the [[Revolution of 1905]] prevented sending scores from Russia for the orchestra to accompany Campanari on arias from Tchaikovsky's ''[[Iolanta]]'' and ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|Queen of Spades]]'' (''Pique Dame''), and the performances were almost canceled. The only known copy of even the texts of the arias that could readily be found in New York was a German translation. The situation was finally rescued by "a little music store on [[Canal Street (Manhattan)|Canal Street]]" which had held the relevant scores in stock, unsold for about a decade after they had been purchased from a Russian tenor in need of cash.<ref>"East Side Junk Yields Music For Campanari", ''New York Times'', 25 December 1905, p. 7.</ref>
Pianist [[Josef Lhévinne]] likewise had an extremely difficult time escaping the turmoil of revolution in Moscow to come to New York to play with the Russian Symphony and others, facing danger from both the revolutionists and the government.<ref>"Lhevinne Risked Life In Flight From Moscow: Young Pianist Arrives with a Tale of Terrors in the City…", ''New York Times'', 16 January 1906, p. 11.</ref> Although his troubles were compounded by an injury to a finger,<ref>"Lhevinne Hurt His Finger: Accident at the Piano Almost Prevented Him From Playing", ''New York Times'', 28 January 1906, p. X2.</ref> his January 27, 1906 performance featured [[Anton Rubinstein]]'s Fifth Concerto, and drew a very favorably review from the ''Times''.<ref>"The Latest Russian Pianist: Josef Lhevinne Makes an Excellent Impression at His First Concert", ''New York Times'', 28 January 1906, p. 7.</ref>
[[File:New Music Society of America - 1906 ad.jpg|thumb|left]] In late December 1905, Altschuler and others announced the formation of the New Music Society of America, soliciting "serious new work" from American composers, with the Russian Symphony functioning as the group's orchestra.<ref>"New Organization Will Have Aid of the Russian Symphony Society, ''New York Times'', 27 December 1905, p. 9.</ref> A first Carnegie Hall concert originally scheduled for February 19 apparently never occurred, because the ''New York Times'' refers to a March 10 concert as the group's first; another concert took place April 2, 1906.<ref>"Music and Music Makers", ''New York Times'', 7 January 1906, p. X1.</ref><ref name="NYT-1906-03-11">"Music by Americans: The First Concert of the New Music Society in Carnegie Hall", ''New York Times'', 11 March 1906, p. 9.</ref> The most prominent pieces at that first concert [[Edward MacDowell]]'s ''[[Indian Suite]]'' and ''Second Concerto'' (hardly "new": although only in his forties, MacDowell was already in his final illness at the time); the orchestra also performed [[Henry F. Gilbert]]'s ''Salammbô's Invocation to Tänith'' and [[Arthur Shepard]]'s ''Overture Joyeuse''.<ref name="NYT-1906-03-11"/> The second concert featured violinist [[Maud Powell]] as a soloist; works included [[George Whitefield Chadwick]]'s ''Melpomene'' overture, the premiere of a violin concerto by [[Henry Holden Huss]], and premieres of pieces by [[David Stanley Smith (composer)|David Stanley Smith]] and [[Frederick Converse]].<ref>"Musical Notes", ''New York Times'', 25 March 1906, p. X4.</ref><ref>"American Music Heard", ''New York Times'', 3 April 1906, p. 9.</ref>
That season, the March 17, 1906 concert featured the first American performance of the young [[Reinhold Glière]]'s ''Symphony No 1 in E-flat major, Op. 8'' (composed 1900) as well as American premieres of pieces by [[César Cui]] a Cossack dance by [[Alexander Serov]], who had died 35 years earlier in an era when Russian music had little currency in America, and 'a new concerto for violin, by Mlinarski," presumably the ''Concerto in D minor'' (composed c. 1897) by the [[Poland|Polish]] composer [[Emil Młynarski]].<ref>"The Russian Symphony", ''New York Times'', 11 March 1906, p. X1.</ref><ref name="NYT-1906-03-18">"New Russian Works", ''New York Times'', 18 March 1906, p. 11.</ref> However, the unrest in Russia at that time prevented Rachmaninoff from visiting America, scuttling his planned April 7 performance.<ref name="NYT-1906-03-18" /> Instead, violinist and composer [[Émile Sauret]] was featured, performing [[Antonín Dvořák]]'s ''[[Violin Concerto (Dvořák)|Violin Concerto in A Minor]]''.<ref name="NYT-1906-04-01">"Russian Symphony Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 1 April 1906. p. X3.</ref><ref>"Emile Sauret Heard Again"", ''New York Times'', 8 April 1906. p. 9.</ref> The same concert included two pieces by composer [[Anton Arensky]], who had died on February 25.<ref name="NYT-1906-04-01" />
===An established orchestra=== By the end of the 1906 season, the Russian Symphony Orchestra was an established part of the New York music scene. In all, the ''New York Times'' counted six New York premieres by the Russian Symphony Orchestra as such in 1906, and three more by the New Music Society.<ref>"Music and Music Makers", ''New York Times'', 22 April 1906. p. C4.</ref> On May 25, the Society announced that Altschuler would be retained as Director for three more years, with Russian Ambassador Baron [[Roman Rosen]] continuing as honorary president.<ref>"Modest Altschuler Re-elected", ''New York Times'', 26 May 1906. p. 11.</ref> Looking forward to the 1906-1907 musical season, the ''Times'' counted them among the city's major orchestras, along with the [[New York Philharmonic]], [[New York Symphony Orchestra]], [[Peoples' Symphony Concerts]], and [[Sam Franko]]'s [[American Symphony]].<ref>Richard Aldrich, "In the World of Music: Prospects of the Season", ''New York Times'', 28 October 1906. p. X6.</ref>
The 1906-7 season saw an appearance by pianist and composer [[Alexander Scriabin]] under the baton of his (and Altschuler's) conservatory teacher [[Vasily Safonov]]. An anonymous ''New York Times'' review praised Scriabin's playing, while finding him immature as a composer. The same reviewer panned [[Alexander Glazunov]]'s ''Third Symphony'', which had its American premiere on this occasion: "[W]hat Russian music the conductor's of the more cosmopolitan orchestras have left for the Russians to put down on their programmes as given 'for the first time' may have been rejected rather than overlooked."<ref>"The Russian Symphony: A Programme of New Works -- Alexander Scriabine Plays His Own Concerto", ''New York Times'', 21 December 1906, p.9.</ref> Apparently undaunted by that criticism, the orchestra announced two days later that its concert of January 17 would feature American premieres of Rachmaninoff's ''[[Spring (Rachmaninoff)|Spring]]'' cantata and [[Jean Sibelius]]'s ''[[Karelia Suite|Karelia]]'' overture,<ref>"Musical notes", ''New York Times'', 23 December 1906, p.X5.</ref> though apparently Rimsky-Korsakov's ''[[Antar (Rimsky-Korsakov)|Antar]]'' was substituted for the Rachmininoff.<ref name="times-1907-01-18">"New Russian Music", ''New York Times'', 18 January 1907, p.7.</ref> ''The Times'' doubled down in its criticism: "[M]any of the things by the Russian composers that we do not know seem upon presentation hardly worth knowing. … ''Antar'' … is no symphony by any recognized definition of the term… This would be nothing against the music if it could win acceptance for itself as music, which it did not last evening."<ref name="times-1907-01-18"/> While continuing its skepticism toward recent Russian music, the ''Times'' had high praise for soloist [[Fannie Bloomfield Zeisler]]'s February 7, 1907 performance of [[Anton Rubenstein]]'s already well-known [[Piano Concerto No. 4 (Rubinstein)|D Minor Concerto (No. 4)]], though suggesting that the orchestra "show[ed] a lack of rehearsal with the pianist."<ref>"Mrs. Zeisler Wins Audience", ''New York Times'', 8 February 1907, p.9.</ref> The fifth of six concerts that season on February 28, featuring a return by pianist Josef Lhévinne, consisted entirely of Russian pieces performed for the first time in America, although they were not recent works. The orchestral introduction of [[Modest Mussorgsky|Mussorgsky]]'s ''[[The Fair at Sorochyntsi]]'' and Rubinstein's ''Caprice Russe'' were both by composers who had died before the turn of the century. [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]]'s ''[[Caucasian Sketches, Suite No. 2|Iveria Suite]]'' (1896) and [[Alexander Scriabin]]'s ''[[Symphony No. 1 (Scriabin)|First Symphony]]'' (completed 1900), while also not particularly recent, were at least by then-living composers, and Scriabin was present for the occasion.<ref>"A Russian Concert: Music for Orchestra and Piano Heard for the First Time", ''New York Times'', 1 March 1907, p.9.</ref>
That summer, Altschuler traveled to Europe to engage soloists for the 1907-1908 season,<ref>"Engages Russian Soloists: Modest Altschuler Tells His Plans For Next Season's Concerts", ''New York Times'', 19 July 1907, p.7.</ref> which began with a special concert November 10 at their largest venue to date: accompanying violinist [[Jan Kubelik]] at the [[New York Hippodrome]].<ref>"Vast Audience at Kubelik Recital", ''New York Times'', 11 November 1907, p.7.</ref> (A similar performance was given the following year, March 15, 1908.<ref>"Kubelik at the Hippodrome", 16 March 1908, p.7.</ref>) Four days later they began their regular season at Carnegie Hall with Russian ambassador [[Roman Rosen|Baron Rosen]] in attendance, and with a program consisting largely of American premieres of Russian pieces: [[Alexander Glazunov]]'s ''[[Symphony No. 8 (Glazunov)|Symphony No. 8]]'', composed roughly two years earlier; arrangements of Russian folk songs by Glazunov, [[Anatoly Lyadov]], and Rimsky-Korsakov; and Mussorgsky's "[[Pictures at an Exhibition#No. 10 "The Great Gate of Kiev"|Great Gate of Kiev]]". The program also featured the American debut of young Russian violinist [[Lea Luboshutz]] (listed at the time as ''Laya Luboshiz''),<ref>"The Russian Orchestra: A Concert of New Compositions in Carnegie Hall", ''New York Times'', 1 November 1907, p.9.</ref> who received eight curtain calls for her solo on Tchaikovsky's ''[[Violin Concerto (Tchaikovsky)|Violin Concerto]]''.<ref>"Of Musical Interest", ''Brooklyn Life'', 23 November 1907, p.15.</ref> She was not the only notable female soloist to play with the orchestra that season: on February 13, 1908, cellist [[May Muklé]] performed [[Karl Davydov]]'s ''Cello Concerto No. 2 in A minor''.<ref>"Russian Symphony Concert", ''New York Times'', 14 February 1908, p.14.</ref>
===Broader recognition and touring=== 1908 also brought unprecedented recognition from Russia itself. The tsar granted the [[Order of Saint Stanislaus]] to orchestra president [[Frank Seymour Hastings]] in recognition of his promotion of Russian music in America.<ref name=czar>"Czar to Honor Musician", ''New York Times'', 5 June 1908, p.7.</ref>
For 1908-1909, the orchestra reduced its Carnegie Hall season from six performances to four,<ref name="1908 plans">"Russian Symphony's Plans", ''New York Times'', 17 September 1908, p.7.</ref> and began taking on other performance opportunities. At Carnegie Hall, they continued to present notable soloists: the debut of [[Mischa Elman]] (19 years old at the time<ref>"Mischa Elman Appears", ''New York Times'', 11 December 1908, p.8. ''The Times'' described him as "an artist already of remarkable powers of whom much that is interesting is to be expected."</ref>), a return by Josef Lhévinne, and also an appearance by [[Alexander Petschnikoff]].<ref name="1908 plans" /> After a November 16, 1908 tryout in [[New Haven, Connecticut]],<ref name="New Haven">"Russian Music With Acting", ''New York Times'', 17 November 1908, p.9.</ref> on February 11, 1909, they collaborated with the [[Ben Greet]] Players on a Carnegie Hall performance of Shakespeare's ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' incorporating [[A Midsummer Night's Dream (Mendelssohn)|Mendelssohn]]'s incidental music,<ref>"Orchestra Aids Greet Players", ''New York Times'', 12 Feb 1909, p.13.</ref> a performance that was repeated at [[Lake George, New York|Lake George]] on August 30<ref>"Lake George: Sylvan Players Begin Dramatic Festival in Natural Amphitheatre", ''New York Times'', 29 August 1909, p.X3.</ref> and at Carnegie Hall on New Year's Day 1910.<ref>"Calendar of Concerts", ''New York Times'', 26 Dec 1909, p.SM13.</ref> These performances constituted the first time Mendelssohn's music was performed in conjunction with the play in the United States.<ref name="1908 plans" /> The two groups collaborated further, including a 1910 production of Shakespeare's ''[[The Tempest]]''<ref>"Russian Orchestra and Greet Players", ''New York Times'', 11 February 1910, p. 11.</ref> and a series of performances in the 1910-1911 season which repeated these pieces and added ''[[As You Like It]]'', ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'', ''[[Macbeth]]'', and ''Sakuntala''.<ref>"Greet Players with Russian Orchestra", ''New York Times'', 27 November 1910, p. 9. The ''Times'' article doesn't elaborate on ''Sakuntala'': presumably one of numerous plays about [[Shakuntala]], a figure in the ''[[Mahabharata]]''.</ref>
Besides a broader variety of New York performances, the orchestra toured extensively.<ref name=Levant /> Although they had already toured in December 1907, when the ''New York Times'' mentions them traveling to "Chicago, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Madison, Wis. and other cities," bringing along pianists [[Ernest Hutcheson]] and [[Ernest Schelling]],<ref>"Music Notes'', ''New York Times'', 8 December 1907, p. X2.</ref> their 1908 touring plans extended as far as the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]].<ref name=czar/> Their tours could involve large numbers of performances. For example, a newspaper from [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] shows the orchestra performing four separate concerts (at 2 p.m., 4 p.m., 7:30 p.m. and 9:30 p.m.) on a single Wednesday in September 1911. The programs were each entirely different, and the music ranged from [[Beethoven]] through [[Richard Wagner]], [[Verdi]] and [[Puccini]] to Sibelius and Scriabin.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1126&dat=19110906&id=p59hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IGYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4773,4128233 Symphony Programs Cause Enthusiasm], ''The Gazette Times'' (Pittsburgh), 6 September 1911, p. 16.</ref>
===The 1910s=== [[File:MaudeAllanSalomeHead.jpg|thumb|right|Maud Allan as Salomé; in the New York performance, "the head itself was left to the imagination, but none of the caressing was."<ref name="NYT-Salomé" />]] The orchestra began the 1910s with a premiere of a different sort. After a January 1 Carnegie Hall reprise of their ''Midsummer Night'' collaboration with Ben Greet, on January 20 their second performance of the new decade introduced dancer [[Maud Allan]] to the New York audience. Although American-born, Allan had begun her dancing career in England and Europe, and this was her first American appearance. Like [[Isadora Duncan]] and [[Loie Fuller]], Allan choreographed for herself, using existing classical pieces. On this occasion she danced a piece on [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] themes, using music from Anton Rubenstein, Mendelssohn, [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]], and [[Edvard Grieg|Grieg]]. The performance alternated Allan's dances with straight orchestral performances.<ref>"Maud Allan in Greek Dances", ''New York Times'', 21 January 1910, p.11.</ref> A concert a week later featured Rachmaninoff as a guest conductor for the American premiere of his ''[[Isle of the Dead (Rachmaninoff)|Isle of the Dead]]'' and as a soloist on his ''[[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Rachmaninoff)|Piano Concerto No. 2]]''.<ref>"Rachmaninoff as Conductor", ''New York Times'', 28 January 1910, p.9.</ref> Further performances with Allan followed, with the dancer performing her signature ''Visions of Salomé'', among other pieces.<ref name="NYT-Salomé">"Maud Allan as Salome", ''New York Times'', 30 January 1910, p.11.</ref><ref>"Miss Allan to Repeat Salome Dance", ''New York Times'', 1 February 1910, p.9.</ref><ref>Display ad, ''New York Times'', 9 February 1910, p.16.</ref><ref>"News of the Musical World", ''New York Times'', 27 February 1910, p. SM15.</ref> On April 4, the orchestra played a benefit for Russian immigrants at the [[Waldorf-Astoria]], featuring several musical soloists as well as ballet dancers [[Anna Pavlova]] and [[Mikhail Mordkin]].<ref>"Music Notes", ''New York Times'', 1 April 1910, p.11.</ref><ref>"Pavlowa Dances for Charity", ''New York Times'', 5 April 1910, p.11.</ref>
The 1910-1911 season featured five Carnegie Hall concerts interspersed with numerous out-of-town shows and followed by a 20-week national tour.<ref>"Plans for Russian Symphony Orchestra Season", ''New York Times'', 12 September 1910, p.9.</ref><ref>"Musical notes", ''New York Times'', 18 September 1910, p.13.</ref> Their New York season began November 17 with a concert that included a very different interpretation of Rachmaninoff's ''Symphony No. 2'', which they had premiered in 1901 and which had meanwhile become a "celebrated" and much-played work. After discussions with the composer, Altschuler had sped up the tempi and his reading of the piece had "radically changed". The concert also featured two American premieres of pieces by [[Anatoly Lyadov]]—''Kikimora'' and ''Volshebnoye ozero (The Enchanted Lake)'', both written in 1909—Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'', and several songs sung by German baritone [[Alexander Heinemann]].<ref>"News of the Music World", ''New York Times'', 13 November 1910, p.X7.</ref><ref>"Rachmininoff Again", ''New York Times'', 18 November 1910, p.9. This is the source for the word "celebrated".</ref> The December 1 concert featured the U.S. debut of Canadian-born violinist [[Kathleen Parlow]]; the ''New York Times'' reviewer described her performance of Tchaikovsky's ''[[Violin Concerto (Tchaikovsky)|Violin Concerto]]'' as a "remarkable achievement" and praised her "unexpected authority",<ref name="NYT 1910-11-27">"The Russian Symphony", ''New York Times'', 27 November 1910, p.X7.</ref><ref name="NYT 1910-12-02">"Russian Symphony Concert", ''New York Times'', 2 December 1910, p.9. This article, the one that refers to her "remarkable achievement", erroneously refers to ''Katherine'' Parlow.</ref> and would have equally high praise for her "consummate technical accuracy…beauty of tone…spirit…[and]fire" when she returned to play [[Henryk Wieniawski]]'s ''[[Violin Concerto No. 2 (Wieniawski)|Violin Concerto No. 2]]'' the following February 2.<ref name="NYT 1911-02-03">"Miss Parlow Applauded", ''The New York Times'', 3 February 1911, p. 9. With reference to the Kajanus, the cited source simply says ''Finnish Rhapsody''. Kajanus wrote two ''Finnish Rhapsodies'', No. 1 in D minor, Op. 5 (1881) and No. 2 in F major (1886); there is no indication of which was performed on this occasion. Also, the ''Times'' refers again to the Rachmaninoff piece as ''The Cliff'' rather than ''The Rock''.</ref> The concert was also the American premier of Stravinsky's ''[[Feu d'artifice]]'' (''Fireworks'').<ref name="NYT 1910-11-27" /><ref name="NYT 1910-12-02"/> who had grown up largely in San Francisco and had become a professional musician in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.collectionscanada.ca/gramophone/m2-1022.1-e.html|title = Kathleen Parlow - Childhood and Education|publisher = Collections Canada}}</ref> Starting four days later, they provided accompaniment for two-week run of [[Maurice Maeterlinck|Maeterlinck]]'s tragedy ''[[Mary Magdalene (Maeterlinck play)|Mary Magdalene]]'' at [[Century Theatre (New York City)|The New Theatre]].<ref>"'Mary Magdalene' for New Theatre", ''New York Times'', 25 November 1910, p.11.</ref><ref>Display ad, ''New York Times'', 5 December 1910, p.18.</ref> This was the world premiere of that play, and the first U.S. performance of any Maeterlinck play.<ref>"Busy Nights for Playgoers", ''New York Times'', 4 December 1910, p.X1.</ref>
A January 19, 1911 concert featured German-Polish pianist and composer [[Xaver Scharwenka]] as the soloist on his own ''Piano Concerto No. 1 in B-flat minor'', as well as the American premiere of the Introduction and Wedding Procession from Rimsky-Korsakov's opera ''[[The Golden Cockerel]]''; the concert also featured Rimsky-Korsakov's ''[[Christmas Eve (opera)#Related works|Christmas Eve Suite]]'' and the American premiere of a waltz that Tchaikovsky had written for ''[[The Nutcracker]]'' but omitted from the final version, and closed with Tchaikovsky's ''[[Marche Slave]]''.<ref>"Music Here and There", ''The New York Times'', 1 Jan 1911, p. X7.</ref><ref>Untitled item after Richard Aldrich, "The Question of Singing Operatio Texts in English Aroused by Mme. Nordica's Offering of a Scene from 'Die Walkuere'", ''The New York Times'', 8 Jan 1911, p. XX7.</ref><ref>"Russian Symphony", ''The New York Times'', 15 Jan 1911, p. X10.</ref><ref>"The Russian Orchestra", ''The New York Times'', 20 Jan 1911, p. 8.</ref> The February 2 concert featured the American premiere of [[Robert Kajanus]]' ''Finnish Rhapsody'', a return of Rachmaninoff's ''The Rock'' (which they had played in their second concert ever), and the return of violinist Kathleen Parlow performing the abovementioned Wieniawski concerto.<ref name="NYT 1911-02-03"/>

{{about|the painting executed in 1480, in the church of Ognissanti|the painting completed in 1494, now in the Uffizi Gallery|Saint Augustine in His Study (Botticelli, Uffizi)|the painting of the same name by Carpaccio|St. Augustine in His Study (Carpaccio)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Sandro botticelli, sant'agostino nello studio, 1480 circa, dall'ex-coro dei frati umiliati, 01.jpg | title=Saint Augustine in His Study | artist=[[Sandro Botticelli]] | year=1480 | type=Fresco | height_metric=152 | width_metric=112 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Florence]] | museum=[[Church of Ognissanti]] }}
'''''Saint Augustine in His Study''''' is a painting of [[Augustine of Hippo]] executed in 1480 by the [[Italian Renaissance]] master [[Sandro Botticelli]]. It is in the church of [[Ognissanti, Florence|Ognissanti]] in [[Florence]].
Botticelli was born in a house in the same street as the church, still called Via Borgo Ognissanti. He was to live within a minute or two's walk of this all his life, and to be buried in the church.<ref>Lightbown, 17–19</ref>
==History== In 1464 Botticelli's father bought a house in Via Nuova nearby (modern Via della Porcellana), which Sandro took over in 1470 and lived in for the rest of his life. Here the notable family on the street were the Vespucci, including [[Amerigo Vespucci]], born in 1454, after whom the Americas were named. The Vespucci were close Medici allies, and would become regular patrons of Botticelli.<ref>Lightbown, 18–19</ref>
The work was commissioned by the Vespucci family, probably Amerigo's father Nastaglio, a [[notary]], and his brother Giorgio Antonio, both neighbours of Botticelli.<ref>Lightbown, 77</ref> Someone else, probably the order running the church,<ref>Lightbown, 77</ref> commissioned [[Domenico Ghirlandaio]] to do a facing ''[[Saint Jerome in His Study (Ghirlandaio)|Saint Jerome]]''; both saints were shown writing in their studies, which are crowded with objects. As in other cases, such direct competition "was always an inducement to Botticelli to put out all his powers", and the fresco, now his earliest to survive, is regarded as his finest by Ronald Lightbown.<ref>Lightbown, 73–78, 74 quoted</ref> Both depicted two Doctors of the Church in their studies, with a number of objects which mark them as scholars and precursors of [[Renaissance Humanism]]. There is known to have been a small painting of Jerome in his study said to have been by [[Jan van Eyck]] in the Medici collection, which is now lost. This may have influenced both frescos.<ref>Legouix, 76</ref>
They decorated the screen of the unusually located choir, which was demolished in 1564–1566, when they were detached and moved to the nave. They are now in the refectory, moved there after sustaining slight damage in the [[1966 flood of the Arno]]. In the first move part of the frame with its inscriptions went lost, and all of Jerome's.<ref>Lightbown, 74–76; Legouix, 76</ref>
==Description== It portrays [[Augustine of Hippo]] in meditation inside his study. The precise subject is a legend, probably first found in the 13th century, of a vision Augustine had as he began to write a letter to [[Jerome]] in his study at Hippo in 420. The time is shown on the clock by his head as the end of the twenty-fourth hour, counting from the previous sunset. This is the hour of [[Compline]], specified in the legend. A light and sweet odour came into his study and a voice told him that "he might as soon enclose the ocean in a small vessel, as soon clasp the whole earth in his fist, as soon halt the movement of the heavens as describe the beatitude of the saints without having experienced it", as the speaker was now doing. When Augustine asked who he was, he replied he was Jerome. Augustine later heard that Jerome had died in [[Jerusalem]] at exactly that hour.<ref>Lightbown, 76–77, 77 quoted</ref>
The coat of arms visible in the upper part is that of the Vespucci family; Jerome has no equivalent arms.<ref>Lightbown, 77</ref>
The lines in the book over the saint's head are mostly meaningless, apart from a line in which reads: ''Dov'è Frate Martino? È scappato. E dov'è andato? È fuor dalla [[Porta al Prato]]'' ("Where is Brother Martino? He went out. And where did he go? He is outside Porta al Prato"), probably referring to the escapades of one of the [[Humiliati|Uumiliati]], the order who ran the church. Lightbown suggests that this shows Botticelli thought "the example of Jerome and Augustine likely to be thrown away on the Umiliati as he knew them".<ref>Lightbown, 77 (different translation to same effect)</ref>
==See also== *[[Saint Augustine in His Study (Botticelli, Uffizi)|''Saint Augustine in His Study'' (Botticelli, Uffizi)]], a later version (1494) of the same subject *[[St. Augustine in His Study (Carpaccio)|''St. Augustine in His Study'' (Carpaccio)]]

{{short description|The flag of Cornwall, England}} {{Redirect|Flag of Cornwall|the flag of the Canadian city of Cornwall, Ontario|flag of Cornwall, Ontario}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox flag |Name = Cornwall |Article = |Image = Flag of Cornwall.svg |Use = 100000 |Nickname = St Piran's Flag |Morenicks = Baner Peran, An Gwynn ha Du |Symbol = |Proportion = 3:5 |Adoption = 19th century |Design = A white cross on a black background. |Type = }} [[File:Pamiatka z Kornwalii.jpg|thumb|right|Souvenir flags outside a café]] [[File:Stpiraninpenwith.JPG|thumb|right|Saint Piran's Day celebrations in [[Penzance]]]] [[File:High ripples from Loe ground.jpg|thumb|right|Flying the flag in [[Portloe]]]] '''Saint Piran's Flag''' ({{lang-kw|Baner Peran}}) is the flag of [[Cornwall]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]]. The earliest known description of the flag as the [[Heraldic standard|Standard]] of Cornwall was written in 1838.[https://www.google.com/books?id=oYYvAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA332&dq=formerly+the+banner+of+St.+Perran 'The Parochial History of Cornwall', by Davies Gilbert. (1838) Vol III, p. 332] It is used by some [[Cornish people]] as a symbol of their identity.[http://www.flaginstitute.org/pdfs/Phil%20Rendle.pdf Phil Rendle, Cornwall – The Mysteries of St Piran, The Flag Institute] It is a white cross, which has a similar design to that of [[Saint George's Cross|Saint George]] on the [[Flag of England|English flag]], that is laid on top of a black background. The flag is attributed to [[Saint Piran]], a 6th-century Cornish abbot. One early use of a white cross and black background design is the 15th-century coat of arms of the Saint-Peran family.P. POTIER de COURCY, Nobiliaire et armorial de Bretagne, A. Aubry, 1862, p390 At the [[Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant]] in June 2012, the flag was among those flown on [[Gloriana (barge)|the Royal Barge, ''Gloriana'']], though this was explained as "innocent" and "nothing constitutional".[https://archive.is/20130505071742/http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/Mystery-Cornish-flag-jubilee-boat-solved/story-16366581-detail/story.html] ==Origins== There are claims that the design dates from prior to 1188 when the flag was used in the [[Crusades]],{{cite web| url=http://www.celticleague.org/flags.html| title= The Six Celtic Flags| website=celticleague.org| dead-url=yes| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060523001540/http://www.celticleague.org/flags.html| archive-date=23 May 2006| access-date=11 September 2017}} and an article in the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' tells that the flag was carried by the [[Cornish people|Cornish]] contingent at the [[Battle of Agincourt]] (1415).Heraldry Society Flag Section Newsletter, Autumn 1969[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gb-corn.html Cornish flag] {{Unreliable source?|date=June 2010}} However, the reference given by the ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' seems to have been confused with one that comes from a 1590 poem entitled ''[[Poly-Olbion]]'' by [[Michael Drayton]]. It states that the banner carried by the Cornish men at Agincourt depicted two [[Cornish Wrestling|Cornish wrestlers]] in a hitch.''Poly-Olbion'' by Michael Drayton The earliest known evidence of this flag was recorded by [[Davies Gilbert]] in his 1838 work: ''The [[Wikt:parochial|Parochial]] History of Cornwall'', in which he gives reference to
a white cross on a black ground [that] was formerly the banner of St Perran and the Standard of Cornwall; probably with some allusion to the black ore and the white metal of tin
The fact that Gilbert identifies it as being "formerly" a standard of Cornwall implies that he believed it to have been used before 1838. However, Gilbert did not leave a record of his background research, and referred only to his "recollection". One of the oldest depictions of the flag can be seen in a stained glass window at [[Westminster Abbey]]. It was unveiled in 1888, in memory of the famous Cornish inventor and engineer [[Richard Trevithick]]. The window depicts [[Michael (archangel)|St Michael]] at the top and nine Cornish saints, Piran, [[Saint Petroc|Petroc]], Pinnock,http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=5453 Germanus, Julian, Cyriacus, [[Constantine (British saint)|Constantine]], [[Saint Non|Nonna]] and [[Geraint of Dumnonia|Geraint]] in tiers below. The head of St Piran appears to be a portrait of Trevithick himself, and the figure carries the banner of Cornwall.[http://www.westminster-abbey.org/our-history/people/richard-trevithick Westminster Abbey] ==Clues to its origin== {{Refimprove section|date=June 2010}} Saint Piran's Flag has similarities to the old [[The Kroaz Du (Black Cross)|Breton flag]] and the [[flag of Saint David]]. The cultural links between [[Brittany]], [[Wales]] and Cornwall are well recorded. Saint Piran's Flag is the negative image of the old Breton flag, a black cross on a white field. The flag of Saint David shares a black background with Saint Piran's Flag, but is surmounted by a gold, rather than a white, cross. [[File:Kroaz Du.svg|The Standard of the Army of the Breton Duchy (cf. [[Kroaz Du]])|thumb]] [[File:Flag of Saint David.svg|The Welsh [[Flag of Saint David]]|thumb]] It has also been suggested that it may have been based on the arms of the [[Earl of Cornwall]], or the later [[Duchy of Cornwall]]; based on the arms of other Cornish families; or be linked with the black and white livery of the [[Knights of St John]]. ==French and Breton family arms== The arms of the Saint-Peran family in Brittany, show a white cross pattee on a black field. File:Borgnearms.jpg|Arms of Geoffroy le Borgne File:Arneke2.jpg|Arms of the Arnèke family File:Rouvroy.jpg|Arms of Rouvroy de Saint-Simon File:Blason de la famille de saint-pezran.svg|Arms of Saint-Pezran family (Brittany)''Guide des drapeaux bretons et celtes'' (English: Guide of Breton and Celtic flags) by Divi Kervella and Mikael Bodlore-Penlaez, published by Yoran Embanner (in French), (2008) {{ISBN|978-2-916579-12-2}} Several other French and Breton families also had [[Coat of arms|coats of arms]] that bear a striking resemblance to the St Piran's flag: * ''Saint Peran'' or ''Saint Pezran'' (= Piran) of [[Brittany]] (from [[Glomel]], in [[Cornouaille]]), is described as, "''sable a cross patée argent''". * [[Geoffroy le Borgne]] of [[Brittany]] is described as "''de sable à croix d'argent''".{{cite web |url=http://www.briantimms.com/vermandois/bretons.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422104633/http://www.briantimms.com/vermandois/bretons.htm |archivedate=22 April 2006 |df=dmy-all }} * Rossillon de Gex, coat of arms described: "''De sable à la croix d'argent''". * Brunet, de la Besse, coat of arms described: "''D'azur, à la croix d'argent''".[http://armorial.free.fr/p%E9rigord/armes_descrip/b_perigord/brunet.html visu_armes_p] * Arnèke Family coat of arms.[http://membres.lycos.fr/paleographie/heraldique/hazebrouck/details/arneke.html La page du généalogiste fou ... L'héraldique] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229052411/http://membres.lycos.fr/paleographie/heraldique/hazebrouck/details/arneke.html |date=29 February 2008 }} * Rouvroy de Saint-Simon of [[Picardy]], described: "''De sable à la croix d'argent chargée de cinq coquilles''".[http://perso.wanadoo.fr/jm.ouvrard/armor/fami/r/rouvroy.htm rouvroy] ==Usage== The flag is often displayed on bumper stickers, and flying from buildings, including those of [[Cornwall Council]].[http://www.cornishstudies.com/index.php?q=node/10 How far has the “Cornish Revival” affected modern Cornwall?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008211307/http://www.cornishstudies.com/index.php?q=node%2F10 |date=8 October 2011 }} It is flown at most Cornish gatherings, such as the [[Gorseth Kernow]], [[St Piran's Day]] (5 March), [[Camborne]]'s Trevithick Day (April), [[Padstow]]'s [['Obby 'Oss festival]] (May), [[Helston]]'s [[Furry Dance|Flora Day]] (May), and at [[Rugby union in Cornwall|Cornish rugby]] matches. It is regularly seen around Cornwall on car stickers with the word ''[[Cornwall|Kernow]]'' (Cornish for Cornwall), and is used around the world as a symbol of the [[Cornish diaspora]] or overseas Cornish associations. It has been adapted for use in the logos of a number of organisations, such as the Cornwall district of the [[Methodist Church]], is used by a variety of Cornish businesses such as [[Ginsters]], and is seen on the design of the [[Cornish All Blacks]] rugby shirts as well as the [[Cornish Pirates]] rugby logo.{{dead link|date=June 2015}} At the [[Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant]] in June 2012, the flag was flown on [[Gloriana (barge)|the Royal Rowing Barge]] alongside the flags representing [[flag of England|England]], [[flag of Scotland|Scotland]], [[St Patrick's Cross|Northern Ireland]], [[flag of Wales|Wales]] and the [[flag of the Corporation of the City of London|City of London]]. One of the largest flags in the pageant was also St Piran's Flag, flown by the St Ives mackerel lugger ''Barnabas''.{{cite web|url=http://www.falmouthpacket.co.uk/news/westcornwall/9745015.St_Ives_lugger_flies_the_flag_at_Jubilee_river_pageant/?ref=rss|title=St Ives lugger flies the flag at Jubilee river pageant|publisher=Falmouth Packet|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=7 June 2012}} The flags of [[Smith Island, Maryland]] and [[Tangier, Virginia]] incorporate St. Piran's cross in the upper-left [[canton (flag)|canton]] in recognition of the early settlers who came to the islands from Cornwall and Devon. ==Gallery== File:Cornish Pirates (logo).jpg|[[Cornish Pirates]] RFC logo showing the Saint Piran's Flag File:Flag of the Duke of Cornwall.svg|The flag of the [[Duke of Cornwall]] == See also == * [[Outline of Cornwall]] * [[List of Cornish flags]] * [[Cornish heraldry]] * [[The Flag of the Duchy of Brittany]] * [[List of topics related to Cornwall]] * [[St Piran's Day]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20031013133459/http://atlasgeo.span.ch/fotw/flags/gb-corn.html Flags of the World] – Speculations of the origins of this flag. * [{{Flag Institute|Cornwall}} The Flag Institute] {{Culture of Cornwall}} {{Celtic nations}} {{Subnational flags of the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Flags of Cornwall]] [[Category:Flags of places in England|Cornwall]] [[Category:Politics of Cornwall]] [[Category:Cornish nationalism]] [[Category:Flags of saints|Piran]] [[Category:Flags with crosses]]

Basilica Sanctae Praxedis {{la icon}} | image= Mosaic of the vault of the chapel of San Zeno (IX century).jpg | caption=Ceiling of the San Zeno chapel. | location= [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | geo = {{coord|41|53|46|N|12|29|55|E|type:landmark_region:IT_scale:10000|display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation=[[Roman Catholic]] | rite= | province= | district= | consecration_year= | status=[[Minor basilica]] | leadership=[[Paul Poupard]] | website= [https://web.archive.org/web/20100124005715/http://www.vicariatusurbis.org/Ente.asp?ID=900 Chiesa Rettoria Santa Prassede] | architect= | architecture_type= [[Church (building)|Church]] | architecture_style= | specifications=yes | facade_direction= [[South-southeast|SSE]] | groundbreaking= 780 | year_completed= 822 | construction_cost= | capacity= | length= {{convert|45|m|ft}} | width= {{convert|30|m|ft}} | width_nave= {{convert|17|m|ft}} | height_max= | materials= }} The '''Basilica of Saint Praxedes''' ({{lang-la|Basilica Sanctae Praxedis}}, {{lang-it|Basilica di Santa Prassede all’Esquillino}}), commonly known in Italian as '''Santa Prassede''', is an ancient [[titulus (Roman Catholic)|titular]] church and [[minor basilica]] in [[Rome]], [[Italy]], located near the papal basilica of [[Saint Mary Major]]. The current [[Cardinal Priest]] of ''Titulus Sancta Praxedis'' is [[Paul Poupard]]. == History == The church in its current form was commissioned by [[Pope Hadrian I]] around the year 780, and built on top of the remains of a 5th-century structure and was designed to house the bones of [[Saint Praxedes]] ({{lang-it|S. Prassede}}) and [[Saint Pudentiana]] ({{lang-it|S. Pudenziana}}), the daughters of [[Saint Pudens]], traditionally [[St. Peter]]'s first Christian convert in Rome. The two female saints were murdered for providing Christian burial for early [[martyr]]s in defiance of Roman law. The basilica was enlarged and decorated by [[Pope Paschal I]] in c. 822. Pope Paschal, who reigned 817-824, was at the forefront of the [[Carolingian Renaissance]] started and advocated by the emperor [[Charlemagne]]. They desired to get back to the foundations of Christianity theologically and artistically. Paschal, thus, began two, linked, ambitious programs: the recovery of martyrs' bones from the [[catacomb]]s of Rome and an almost unprecedented church building campaign. Paschal dug up numerous skeletons and transplanted them to this church. The ''Titulus S. Praxedis'' was established by [[Pope Evaristus]], around 112. The inscriptions found in Santa Prassede, a valuable source illustrating the history of the church, have been collected and published by Vincenzo Forcella.V. Forcella, ''Inscrizioni delle chese e d' altre edifici di Roma, dal secolo XI fino al secolo XVI'' Volume II (Roma: Fratelli Bencini, 1873), pp. 489-524. The church provided the inspiration for [[Robert Browning]]'s poem "The Bishop Orders His Tomb at Saint Praxed's Church." == Interior == [[File:Santa prassede rome.ogv|thumb|left|upright=1.3|Interior of Santa Prassede]] The main altarpiece is a canvas of ''St Praxedes Gathering the Blood of the Martyrs'' (c. 1730-35) by [[Domenico Muratori]]. === Mosaic === [[File:Byzantine mosaics, years 817-824.jpg|thumb|Byzantine mosaics, years 817-824]] The most famous element of the church is the [[mosaic]] decorative program. Paschal hired a team of professional mosaicists to complete the work in the apse, the apsidal arch, and the triumphal arch. In the apse, Jesus is in the center, flanked by Sts. Peter and Paul who present Prassede and Pudenziana to God. On the far left is Paschal, with the square halo of the living, presenting a model of the church as an offering to Jesus. Below runs an inscription of Paschal's, hoping that this offering will be sufficient to secure his place in heaven. On the apsidal arch are twelve men on each side, holding wreaths of victory, welcoming the souls into heaven. Above them are symbols of the four Gospel writers: Mark, the lion; Matthew, the man; Luke, the bull; and John, the eagle, as they surround a lamb on a throne, a symbol of Christ's eventual return to Earth. {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage=[[File:Apsis mosaic S Prassede Rome W1.JPG|210px]] | video1 = [http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/santa-prassede.html Santa Prassede (Praxedes)], [[Smarthistory]]}} Those mosaics, as well as those in the Chapel of [[Saint Zeno]], a funerary chapel which Pope Paschal built for his mother, Theodora,{{cite web|url=http://www.arttrav.com/rome/santa-prassede-mosaics/ |title=The Chapel of Saint Zeno at Santa Prassede: mosaic revival and survival |publisher=ArtTrav |date= |accessdate=4 March 2014}} are the best-known aspects of the church. Also noteworthy are ancient frescoes. Ascending a spiral staircase, one enters a small room, covered in scaffolding; on the wall is a fresco cycle, dating most likely from the 8th century. The frescoes probably depict the life-cycle of the name saint of the church, Praxedes.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} === Pillar of the Flogging === [[File:Monti - santa Prassede colonna flagellazione 01396.JPG|thumb|left|upright|The Column of the Flagellation.]] Santa Prassede also houses an alleged segment of the pillar upon which [[Jesus]] was [[Flagellation of Christ|flogged and tortured]] before his crucifixion in [[Jerusalem]]. The relic is alleged to have been retrieved in the early 4th century by Saint [[Helena (empress)|Helena]] (mother of the [[Roman Emperor]] [[Constantine I]]) who at the age of eighty undertook a [[pilgrimage]] to the [[Holy Land]], where she founded churches for Christian worship and rescued relics associated with the crucifixion of Jesus on [[Calvary]]. Among these legendary relics retrieved by Helena, which included pieces of the [[True Cross]] (now venerated at [[St. Peter's Basilica]][http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/13369b.htm Basilica of St. Peter], with fragments in [[Santa Croce in Gerusalemme]], also in Rome) and wood from the Jesus' crib enshrined at S. Maria Maggiore. The authenticity of these relics, including the Santa Prassede pillar, is disputed by historians, due to lack of forensic evidence and the proliferation of falsified relics during the [[Middle Ages]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} == Titulus == Among known titulars of this see are Lambertus Scannabecchi (later [[Pope Honorius II]], c. 1099), Ubaldo Allucingoli (later [[Pope Lucius III]], 1141), [[Alain de Coëtivy]] (1448), Giovanni Maria Ciocchi del Monte (later [[Pope Julius III]], 1542-1543), Saint [[Charles Borromeo]] (1538-1584), [[Rafael Merry del Val]] (1903-1930).[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/d1p11.html ''S. Prassede (Cardinal Titular Church)''] ==Gallery== File:Santa Prassede - plan.JPG|Plan. File:Santa Prassede Façade.jpg|Internal Façade File:Santa prassede 051218-01.JPG|Entrance File:Santa Prassede (Rome) - Interior.jpg|Interior of Santa Prassede. File:Apsis mosaic S Prassede Rome W6.JPG File:Mosaic of the vault of the chapel of San Zeno (IX century).jpg|Ceiling of the Saint Zeno chapel. File:S Prassede Krypta Rome W1.JPG|Crypt. File:Apsis - Paschalis I..gif|[[Pope Paschal I]], presenting a model of the church to Christ. His square [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]] indicates he was alive when the mosaic was made. File:GBSantoni.jpg|Funerary monument of Bishop [[Giovanni Battista Santoni]] († 1592). Bust by [[Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini]] (c. 1612). File:Domenico Pestrini Tesauro Beccaria.jpg|San Tesauro Beccaria by Domenico Pestrini. File:Tomb of Giovanni Carbone.jpg|Tomb of [[Giovanni Carbone]] (14th century) == References == {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * B. M. Apollonj Ghetti, ''Santa Pra''ssede (Roma: Edizioni Roma, 1961). * Gillian Vallance Mackie, ''The Iconographic Programme of the Zeno Chapel at Santa Prassede, Rome'' [M.A. University of Victoria (B.C., Canada) 1985]. * Marchita B. Mauck, “The Mosaic of the Triumphal Arch of Santa Prassede: A Liturgical Interpretation.” ''Speculum'' 62-64 (1987), pp. 813-828. * [[Rotraut Wisskirchen]], ''Mosaikprogramm von Santa Prassede in Rom'' (Münster: Aschendorff, 1990). * Anna Maria Affanni, ''La chiesa di Santa Prassede: la storia, il rilievo, il restauro'' (Viterbo: BetaGamma, [2006]) [Testimonianze di restauri, 5]. * Mary M. Schaefer, ''Women in Pastoral Office: The Story of Santa Prassede, Rome'' (New York, NY: Oxford University Press, 2013). * Maurizio Caperna, ''La basilica di Santa Prassede: il significato della vicenda architettonica'' (Roma: Edizioni Quasar, 2013). * Benedictine Monks of Vallombroso, ''The Basilica of Saint Praxedes, in memory of their eighth century of presence at Saint Praxedes: 1198-1998'' (Genova, Italia: B.N. Marconi, Fourth Edition, January 2014). == External links == {{Commons|Basilica di Santa Prassede (Roma)}} * [http://kunsthistorie.com/galleri/index.php?album=Italia%2FRoma%2FSan.+Prassede&sortby=name&order=asc Kunsthistorie.com], photogallery. *[http://www.paradoxplace.com/Perspectives/Rome%20&%20Central%20Italy/Rome/Rome_Churches/Santa_Prassede/Santa_Prassede.htm Santa Prassede Mosaics] *High-resolution 360° Panoramas and Images of [https://mcid.mcah.columbia.edu/art-atlas/ancient-and-early-christian-sites-rome-panoramas-world-architecture/santa-prassede Santa Prassede | Art Atlas] == See also == * [[Episcopa Theodora]] {{Churches in the City of Rome}} {{Rome landmarks}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Santa Prassede}} [[Category:822 establishments]] [[Category:9th-century churches]] [[Category:Basilica churches in Rome|Prassede]] [[Category:Titular churches|Prassede]] [[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Churches of Rome (rione Monti)|Prassede]] [[Category:9th-century establishments in Italy]]

[[Medal "For the Defence of Leningrad"]] }} '''Semion Aronovich Rotnitsky''' ({{lang-ru|Семён Аронович Ротницкий}}; December 28, 1915, [[Minsk]], [[Russian Empire]] — 2004, [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Russians|Russian]] painter, Honored Art worker of [[Tatar Republic]], a member of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] (before 1992 — the Leningrad Union of Artists),''Справочник членов Ленинградской организации Союза художников РСФСР.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1987. C.111. who lived and worked in [[Leningrad]]. Rotnitsky is regarded as one of representatives of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad school of painting]],''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' Saint Petersburg, NP-Print Edition, 2007. P.9, 18, 20, 21, 24, 391, 393, 394, 396, 398-406, 439, 445. most famous for his portrait paintings. From 1948 through 1960 he was senior lecturer and director of the [[Kazan Art School]]. His memoirs are titled "The Strength of Beauty".''Ротницкий С. Сила красоты. Записки художника''.
